review_text: Continue nurturing the supportive culture and focus on career progression. As we enter the next decade, keep investing in people and innovation- it’s what has made this company stand out
review_liked_text: Celebrating 10 years with Mastercard has been an incredible journey. The company has evolved tremendously - from a small, ambitious team to a mature organization with a strong culture of collaboration and innovation. Leadership genuinely cares about employee development, providing continuous opportunities to learn and grow. The work environment encourages creativity, open communication, and teamwork. Benefits and work-life balance have steadily improved over the years, reflecting management’s commitment to long-term employee satisfaction.
review_disliked_text: Like any fast-growing company, there have been growing pains -  adapting to new systems and scaling processes can be challenging. However, leadership is transparent and receptive to feedback, which makes change easier to navigate.

review_liked_text: Working in Business experimentation is extremely rewarding in the first few years. You are given the opportunity to interact with clients almost right away, learn great data engineering skills, and learn to think scientifically about business problems. Great 401k match, generous PTO
review_disliked_text: The pay is not competitive compared with other consulting firms, and there even seems to be downward pressure on salaries in some areas. You are forced to staff 3-4 projects at once- hours can be grueling at times. Additionally, Mastercard does not seem to be giving Test & Learn its due attention- we are understaffed at the junior level, and there seems to be no plan to bring hiring back up to previous levels. Integration into Mastercard has brought perverse incentives to sell our services to preexisting Mastercard client businesses who don’t really want our product. Working with these clients is extremely frustrating. What was once a strong, dynamic consulting firm geared toward the best clients is now a small cog in Mastercard’s global business

review_text: Stop with the micro managing and forcing people into an office that doesn’t have space. It creates a hostile environment with people fighting over a desk every day. It says remote work can be requested but the VPs always say “we are not changing any positions to remote at this time”. Let team managers make that decision since VPs don’t know any of the people that work under them. Pay is lower than other companies, so at least work with us in other areas.
review_liked_text: Benefits such as 401k, sick leave, etc
review_disliked_text:
Some of the upper management is bias. For example the last 8 promotions in my dept have been in India teams only, while people on USA teams are told “there’s no budget for promotions”. Great place to work if Indian, otherwise don’t expect a promotion. 
Mandatory 3 days in office is ridiculous, especially when there’s 2 people for every desk. So many times people can’t find a parking spot and have to come back later. Or if they find a spot, they have no open desk. And yet they monitor everyone’s badging in/out. 12+ hour work days, so much micro managing. Been with MC a long time, since Ajay left the company has become worse. They have employee surveys and many complain about the in office policy but upper management changes nothing.

review_text: Fire your mirrors. They’re clearly lying to you. Then try something wild: reward real work. Promote humility. Kill the silos. And maybe walk through the building and acknowledge the people who made you look good for years. Would I recommend to a friend? Not unless I secretly hated them.
review_liked_text: The logo. The stock price. The ability to tell people at parties, “Yeah, I work for Mastercard,” and watch them assume it’s a cutting-edge, collaborative, high-performing company. (It wasn’t.)
review_disliked_text:
Where to begin? Mastercard is the poster child for corporate silos where every department is an island and collaboration is more myth than mandate. Want to make an impact (especially in Comms)? Better bring a bullhorn and a selfie stick, because self-promotion is the only currency that matters. Quietly doing great work? No one will notice, especially not the EVPs (Especially in Marketing and Comms) who won’t make eye contact unless you’re one of their chosen ones (loud, shiny, or politically useful).

Ageism? Rampant. If you’re over 45, you’re either being quietly pushed out or being told to “refresh your personal brand.” Sexism? Yes, just not the direction you’d expect. Some departments are silently dismissive of men and reward behavior that would raise HR eyebrows elsewhere.

Culture-wise, it’s a lot of performative values with little substance. Mastercard loves to say the right things on an HR poster, but the reality is a rigid hierarchy where actual innovation is stifled by layers of approval and ego.

review_text: Unless the role is onsite work required, please open more positions under multiple locations to open the door to additional qualified candidates. Some locations have limited to no seats available yet the jobs are posted at these locations with no work location flexibility offered.
review_liked_text:
- Strong Company Mission and Values
- "Doing Well by Doing Good" to support nonprofits and communities
- Flexible work schedules at most offices
- Strong overall benefits supporting health and wellness
review_disliked_text:
- If you're not based at one of the highest headcount locations, such as New York or St. Louis, in the U.S., you will have limited to no career progression opportunities. There's an internal mechanism to search for internal job moves but recruiters and hiring managers rarely offer location flexibility in their new positions despite being a global organization working under a hybrid work approach. This means a lot of us are trapped in dead-end jobs. 
- Salary is below market for same-titled positions.
- If you're not working at one of those highest headcount locations, you won't receive the same recognition for your work and may have less overall opportunities as a result. Additionally, you won't receive the same level of onsite offerings, resources, support, and/or amenities.

review_text: Shut down identity or merge it with some other department. They only land up wasting employees time and career

review_disliked_text: I joined the Identity department, its the worst ever. No strategy, so called leaders keep changing their own decisions every 6 months to save their jobs. Coworkers were good. There is a Product Marketing team or engagement within Identity, their so called leader and entire seattle team is non-inclusive and racist, very bad experience

review_liked_text: Great Benefits. Amazing 401k match. 25 Vacation days plus 5 personal days (last I worked there) Good pay. Good Culture. Amazing leads and mentors as a Software Engineer 1 coming out of college.
review_disliked_text: Nothing bad to say about it. I was proud to be a Software Engineer at Mastercard. It's just a shame my position was affected by the 9/2024 re-org and layoffs.

review_liked_text: They do have solid 401k and tuition reimbursement benefits
review_disliked_text:
I am a black woman that worked in the Seattle cybersecurity team and was unfortunate to experience the following 

1. Punitive management style with petty nitpicking , ever shifting expectations and poor mentorship and support.
2. Performance reviews were inconsistent and even if you meet specific objectives, they will either cancel meetings or avoid talking about performance measurements
3. Cowardice on the part of leadership. Will miscommunicate and encourage turf wars and pretend you are the one at fault. 
4. Will undermine and take credit for your work leaving you to spiral in self doubt and shame 
5. Cannot trust what leadership says . recording and writing down information will not help you and HR will back them up. The 6 month trial policy also helps to support this. 
6. Be very careful in your written and spoken communication, you would be shocked at their ability to spin untrue narratives. 
7. If you are the kind of person that assumes truth is self evident and will prevail. I  encourage you to abandon that naivete and seek other opportunities

review_liked_text: Everyone is very helpful and there is a lot to learn. Great benefits, inlcuding 10% 401k match and 5 weeks of vacation
review_disliked_text: It can feel slow somedays and O'Fallon, MO is not he most appealing place

review_text: At Mastercard, we treat every hire as a professional. That means being a self-starter—someone who takes initiative and sets up their own mentoring and management check-ins. If you don’t know something, speak up. The culture here rewards proactive communication and the kind of ‘managing up’ that builds trust and drives progress.
review_liked_text: Mastercard offers a collaborative environment where individual contributions are acknowledged and valued. Throughout my tenure, I have participated in meaningful projects and received recognition for both results and teamwork. Dedicating extra time for testing or providing support to colleagues during challenging periods exemplifies the emphasis Mastercard places on accountability, empathy, and high standards. For professionals seeking career growth within an organization committed to purpose and development, Mastercard provides such opportunities.
review_disliked_text: The only potential challenge may arise for individuals who prefer a slower-paced or less dynamic environment, as Mastercard's culture is inherently energetic, innovative, and focused on continuous learning.

review_text:
The Services division struggles to produce meaningful value, innovation or sustainable business impact due to a culture that discourages dissent and rewards passive compliance.

There are leaders with titles including AI and analytics who lack even foundational knowledge of data concepts like schemas. This level of incompetence is not only inefficient but also damaging to morale and credibility. Until leadership prioritizes merit, transparency, and accountability, the organization will continue to underperform relative to its potential.
review_liked_text: There are many smart, kind, intelligent people across the organization who are a pleasure to work with.
review_disliked_text:
Widespread issues with unqualified leadership, scapegoating, and retaliation.

I experienced multiple instances of peers being scapegoated and retaliated against for management failures or constructive criticism. This is prevalent within the Services division.

review_text: When internal employees refer candidates, it would be helpful to receive updates at each stage of the hiring process. Often, we refer people from our trusted network but don’t get notified after the referral is submitted. Improving visibility and communication around referral progress would encourage more engagement and trust in the process.
review_liked_text:
Empowered, Supported, and Inspired at Mastercard: 

Working at Mastercard has been an incredibly rewarding journey. The culture of inclusion, innovation, and collaboration makes it a truly great place to grow. I’ve had the opportunity to work with brilliant minds, take on meaningful projects, and continuously develop my skills. The support from leadership and the positive energy across teams make every challenge feel like a shared mission. Proud to be part of a company that values both people and progress.
review_disliked_text: With so many exciting initiatives happening across teams, prioritization can be a challenge—but it also means there’s never a dull moment. Continuous learning and adaptability are key to thriving here

review_text: Stand behind our sustainability goals by eliminating unnecessary commuting. Realize how out of touch it seems to have executive spaces that can be booked and hot desks in the hot zone (COVID currently circulating). If you truly care about employees--our health and our work/life balance--rethink the new 2024 rules dictating butt-in-seat management. Realize how fundamentally this is changing management's relationship with its workforce.
review_liked_text: Mastercard is wonderfully collegial, and has generous pay and benefits. Six months ago, when someone asked me about work I unequivocally said that I loved my job.
review_disliked_text: The return to office policy moved me from considering Mastercard a place I love to work to one I don't. Dictating days of the week back in the office shows a lack of trust for the workforce, despite all the HR-speak otherwise. Having one desk for every two to three employees has made for a Hunger Games office situation. The CEO stating this was because younger workers crave face time has been seen as 'blaming' them--and they argue that this is not something they want, either.

review_liked_text: Super competitive pay and benefits for market, nice people, generally progressive culture
review_disliked_text: Lack of upward mobility in some departments, workload can be high

review_liked_text: After 20 years in university administration and teaching, joining Mastercard was the best career move I’ve made! In my 5.6 years here, I’ve experienced a culture of respect, kindness, and growth. The Services team is outstanding, and leadership genuinely supports our development. Work-life balance is a true priority—45 PTO days annually (including vacation, personal, sick, and volunteer time), flexible schedules, and a supportive environment make it easy to thrive both personally and professionally. The compensation package is generous, and the office vibe is professional, comfortable, and fun.

review_liked_text: Mastercard offers a wide array of benefits across its credit card tiers (Standard, World, and World Elite). These benefits are designed to enhance security, provide convenience, and offer various perks for cardholders.
review_disliked_text: When evaluating the drawbacks or "cons" associated with Mastercard, it's important to differentiate between general credit card drawbacks and those specific to the Mastercard network. Many potential pitfalls are inherent in credit card usage regardless of the network, while others relate to the network's features or comparison with competitors like Visa.

review_liked_text: The company offers an excellent benefits package, particularly with its 401(k) plan and generous time-off policies.
review_disliked_text: It’s politically charged. If you believe that hard work opens opportunities, this company may not be a good fit. If you communicate well and know how to present in PowerPoint, promotions can come quickly.

review_liked_text: 401k matching is top tier.
review_disliked_text: Work life balance can vary between teams.

review_liked_text: Mastercard has great work life balance, flexible hybrid policy, great PTO even at junior levels, lots of opportunities for lateral movement, education stipend. Overall a great place to work, very comfortable.
review_disliked_text: Pay is low relative to other tech companies, but of course, high compared to the average US income. The company is incredibly bloated in the middle, with most of the company consisting of Directors and limited opportunities to advance beyond that. T&E is extremely limited, with many teams never having met in person across offices. The company could move quicker and be more innovative.

review_text: Get rid of the entire global marketing organization as it's 100% overhead and useless. Question what the heck consumer marketing does...as they don't touch consumers. Stop launching products that don't work. Stop growing the global groups unless they have sales targets. Put product marketing with product as marketing doesn't care about it. Figure out the difference between sales and partner marketing. People have quiet quit in spirit but are physically in the office. PS - this Decency Quotient stuff is BS because there are so many indecent behaviors and no matter what they say, they're not a tech company. And get rid of the stupid Priceless perfume! Who is buying that?
review_liked_text:
Good Benefits

Almost bullet proof business model
review_disliked_text: Horrible culture with very passive aggressive, unprofessional behaviors. Favoritism. Everything is "Priceless" but no customer knows what it means. Marketing makes investments it can't afford so then needs to "sell" them to customers. There are no budgets that would be considered sustainable at normal companies. Constant reorgs and layoffs and then you learn the company acquires a new cybersecurity or AI company. It's constant people pruning. Management is very poor and ego driven. Product launches so called products that don't work so they have to get partners, do perpetual pilots and then buy the company. Meantime Fintechs are laughing. If credit cards ever go away, lord help us. Not a diverse culture at all unless you're Indian. Sorry, it's true.

review_text: The company was more successful the company had a culture that was more than KPIs,  and reports.  When you're treated as a  number and an expense, you'll  end up with employees that treat YOU as disposable.  At one point, I felt that MasterCard was a company I'd retire from.   Now I don't think I'd even want to come back.
review_liked_text: Benefits. Time off. 401k. Work life balance
review_disliked_text:
Layoffs while still hiring. Layoffs after hiring people to the same team just weeks prior. Company culture declined with new CEO. Too much bureaucracy when trying to Get Work Done. One of the core tenants was to Work Quickly, but there is so much red tape, things take forever to Get Done. Too much middle management. For example, I was laid off by someone 3 layers higher than me, but none of the layers between knew. That tells me that a decision was made based not on value, but by some numbers with no context around them.
DEI , ESG, and other 'efforts' make for a great workplace, as long as you're on a work visa. There's a lot of hiring within cultural backgrounds, and it's not always because of merit. I've witnessed it first-hand.

review_liked_text: Great Benefits and team culture
review_disliked_text: Big Company with slower work processes

review_liked_text: Work life balance, great people
review_disliked_text: Limited growth opportunities within certain teams

review_text: When people are shouting from the mountain tops for risks and issues listen and cut the poor performers vs laying off good ones and then replacing them with cheap, poor performing India contractors.  The facts and data are there, just look at them!
review_liked_text: 401k match, bonuses are what keep most people here
review_disliked_text:
The culture is at an all time low. This company will constantly over hire because adding more bodies makes things go faster right? The under productive employees get to just hang out while the over-performing ones do 80% of the work. Due to the piles of paperwork needed to let someone go, 
a poor performer just gets moved team to team and drains everyone else. The new CEO is so far detached from how horrible the culture has become and clearly is just trying to fill his pockets. Ajay the prior CEO was amazing and I was happy during that era. I am embarrassed to work here some days. Layoffs used to be infrequent, now they are happening constantly but we as employees are coached to say "they just left the company". A whole organization of extremely stressed individuals and managers that spend their days on meetings 8+ hours a day instead of supporting their employees.

review_liked_text: Mastercard overall is good to work for, they pay well with good benefits. Good vacation time and 401k match as well as allowing hybrid working.
review_disliked_text: They require 3 days/ week in office with no flexibility on that requirement. They track badge swipes which does not create a good environment. The office environment is very bad. The parking is a limited, the desks are so close you could touch the person sitting next to you, and they are extremely loud because they pack so many people into such a small space. Additionally, there is no assigned seating so you are often left searching for a desk and hoping you find one with working monitors, keyboard, etc. Additionally, you are often left sitting by complete strangers which tends to defeat the point of coming into office.

review_text: The Purchase and St. Louis offices offer exceptional work environments, characterized by outstanding benefits and a supportive atmosphere
review_liked_text:
Amazing benefits.
Purchase and St. Louis have an outstanding environment to work.
review_disliked_text: If you're seeking a company that prioritizes merit and the value of your work over favoritism, this organization may not align with your expectations. For instance, many employees (example: Miami office) retain their positions due to favoritism and proficiency in PowerPoint presentations, rather than a deep understanding of the company's products. This contrasts with the more product-focused environments in the Purchase and St. Louis offices.

review_text: Transparency is key. I think after Ajay left we do not hear everything openly and transparently. Lots of questions about these organizational changes that are not being properly articulated at the bottom of the company. I think it's turned into a one-way street where it's now a top-down approach with no active listening. Work has increased but salaries don't increase much.

- Due to the red tape and the regulatory restrictions/industry, engineering teams tend to move very slowly and they don't work in harmony with other teams. 
- Depending on what program you work at, you will probably see a lot of politics.
- If you know people you can grow in your career very quickly, even if you do not have the right skillsets. 
- So many organizational changes make it impossible to understand the big picture and the long-term roadmap.

review_text:
Trust your employees to do what’s right for the company, their teams and their families.   The world of work has changed. 

Alternatively Mastercard Leadership should just say what you mean by this, that you don’t trust your employees to do the right thing.
review_liked_text: Stable company, good growth trajectory, kind culture
review_disliked_text:
Mastercard recently announced a 3 day per week RTO with a bizarre micromanagement clause that average days in office have to include Mondays and Fridays. 
This follows a 2023 push and very public announcement that teams are trusted here to build their own flex-work agreements and do what works best for them. 
Without giving flex agreements time to come to life, leadership pivoted and put out an RTO mandate. 
Employees everywhere are complaining that this is corporate babysitting at its finest. Even before Covid we weren’t being monitored at this level. 
Mastercard’s leadership approach is proving to be the old school financial institution model that the organization claims to be breaking away from.

Bonus is title based. Will not receive a penny more if you outperform. Evaluations are incredibly subjective. H1-B slaveship.

review_text: Promote individuals to leadership positions that want to lead, not that want to rule. Work on aligning expectations from the top down and bottom up. Listen more closely to the delivery level employees when working to solve problems, rather than solving at a high level - this will reduce oversight of important contextual information,
review_liked_text: Good willingness to accommodate family needs / work-life balance. Willingness and time allowed for giving back to the community and volunteering. Pay felt appropriate for job level.
review_disliked_text:
Multiple layers of management which can be a challenge to navigate. Some people leaders are just promoted to that position because they were good at what they did prior, not necessarily because they were good leaders - this resulted in some managers being poorly suited for the role.
Upper management (C-suite) often not on the same page as the delivery level employees in terms of direction. This resulted in expectations not aligning and projects being reworked causing stress all along the line. I felt this came from the multiple layers of management that directives had to go through and ended up with a 'telephone game' outcome - the delivery level were given direction that did not meet C-Suite expectations.
A mindset of reacting to changes as opposed to being proactive and building products that wouldn't require a lot of manual intervention to sustain.

review_text: Allow for more employee feedback on where process bottlenecks are, so the company can devote resources to places most in need.
review_liked_text: As far as large companies go, Mastercard tries to do right by employees and employs kind empathic people. Managers generally care about their reports and try to do right by their teammates. Culture is strong.
review_disliked_text: Slow-moving company given its crucial place in the payments ecosystem. It pretends to 'move fast', but that's more of a goal than a reality.

review_text: Fire unethical, immoral senior managers such as the senior managers that allow retaliation of sexual discrimination or quid pro quo sexual harassment; instead of allowing the victims to be pushed out of the company. Understand that women and non-white employee can also by harassing white employees. In my experience management was unable or unwilling to recognize this possibility. Fire senior managers when they fail to uphold company values and mission statements.  Don't allow employees or mangers of any lever to disrespect employees constitutional and/or civil rights.
review_liked_text: Hard to think of any.
review_disliked_text: In my opinion the culture includes extreme reverse racism and toxic feminism driven by Facebook trolls that are retaliating against civil rights violation reporting; via both sexual discrimination and harassment. Senior, middle and low level management believe anything without verifying the facts. Same with false rumors spread amongst the rank-and-file. In my opinion interviewing and onboarding was a complete waste of time because of the unprofessional nature of this extremely toxic culture.

review_text:
You'll never be able to keep up with the competitive technology companies with this culture.
- Fire people who are bad at their jobs it's driving away your A-team
- Get a rubric for hiring - analyze your data on what to look for and what to avoid my goodness
- Stop redoing Studio and hire disciplined product people and hard-working salespeople
- For goodness sake let people have some fun in the office regularly. Management only values culture when they're talking points.
- Learn from your acquisitions! It's like it's the first time every time and there are no lessons learned.
review_liked_text:
People become very content here because the pay is good and you don't have to work that hard. This has created a systemic culture problem. But if you want to float, you can have a long career here making PowerPoint and attending meetings all day. The majority of people are "nice." I have met some amazing people but the gems are rare.
- Salary 
- Vacation time (20 days plus volunteer/sick days, good maternity/paternity)
- Mentorship (you have to find them and nurture them!)
- Promotions available (have to ask before the cycle starts)
- Good values around financial inclusion, diversity, giving back, etc.
review_disliked_text:
Every team has issues. There's so much animosity in this org and Mastercard can't/won't identify and remove these people or correct the problems/address concerns.
- Uninspired, disconnected workforce (junior/mid-level slackers, high-ego leaders that don't realize their direct reports stink)
- Bureaucracy (nothing gets done quickly here)
- Conservative business practices (poor hiring/slow firing, pitful budget for regular employee events, etc.)

Stay away if you...
- Get frustrated working somewhere with a lot of duds. 75% of the people I worked with were unmotivated (all talk, no work), 20% were fine, and 5% were go-getters. 
- Feel unsure how much you like/care about payments. It's very boring unless you are a self-identifying payments nerd.
- Expect your company to facilitate bonding with coworkers. Despite billions in revenue, they don't throw regular office gatherings. Mastercard is very stingy.
- Avoid global teams if you don't want calls at crazy hours
- Hate networking internally

review_text:
Address Workplace Politics: Taking steps to mitigate internal politics and promote merit-based advancement may enhance employee satisfaction.
Support Work-Life Balance: Encouraging a healthier work-life balance by managing workloads and setting realistic expectations could improve overall employee well-being.
review_liked_text:
Global Exposure: Working at Mastercard provides exposure to international markets and diverse teams, enriching the professional experience.
Professional Development: The company offers ample opportunities for learning and growth, with senior employees often providing mentorship and guidance.
review_disliked_text:
High-Pressure Environment: Some employees report a fast-paced and intense work environment, which can lead to long hours and encroachment on personal time.
Office Politics: There are mentions of internal politics affecting decision-making and career progression, which can be a source of frustration.

review_text: Listen to your employees, let them actually grow. Get with the times and adopt new processes. There are better ways.
review_liked_text: The Benefits are incredibly good.
review_disliked_text: You will be working as if you are a contractor. Regardless of your skills and experience you will work on whatever is assigned to your team and must "be a team player" even if it doesn't align with your career goals. There is preferential treatment to local employees, remote workers are literally expected to deliver more work. They follow a modified Agile process so you get all of the meetings with none of the benefits. Story points are treated as a time commitment, they've predetermined velocity for every team. The release process is cutting edge and straight out of 2005. Most things are dated, so if you are looking to work with the latest and greatest technology that isn't happening. There is a severe lack of coding standards, tech debt is never addressed.

review_liked_text: Mastercard is an incredible place to work, with a strong emphasis on innovation, diversity, and employee well-being. The company has a clear vision and is dedicated to staying at the forefront of the payments industry, investing heavily in technology and digital solutions. I’ve found the leadership team to be supportive and transparent, which fosters a collaborative and inclusive environment.
review_disliked_text: As with any large company, some processes can feel a bit bureaucratic. Rapidly scaling teams can sometimes lead to competing priorities across projects. However, the management is aware and actively working to streamline processes.

review_text: Start by sharing your actual vision for new areas in more detail than a tag line like "trust is out business" and perhaps consider a restructure of who drives innovative areas - as much as I hate to suggest another reorg I know of no one who doesn't think this needs a new leadership style
review_liked_text: Mastercard is a stable company that treats their employees well - incredible 401k match and there are many smart people that work here. Recognizable name for resume and a good place to start your career
review_disliked_text: There are essentially two groups at Mastercard - the folks who value stability and are lifers and those who join after buying the positioning of MA being an innovative company and leave within 3 years. In my experience, if you are looking to be inspired it will be hard to find within the EVP leadership team who are political and not strategic thinkers. Constant priority churn to try to meet short term revenue targets and try to make ROI from the train wreck of acquisitions done over the course of the last few years, a complete lack of vision in what should be the more innovative teams, silos abound as does busywork and inside out thinking, and despite talk of transparency and working together there is little to no leadership to fulfill that vision - but plenty of name dropping of who talked to the CEO or  last. Very slow moving technology process that will drive anyone coming from an actual agile organization mad and severely outdated business processes that will be unrecognizable for anyone coming from a high growth SAAS company

review_disliked_text:
Most people (especially juniors) are dissatisfied with the company and are looking to leave. Even with a "non-hierarchical" culture, it is apparent they don't care about the junior employees. The institutional knowledge is incredibly weak, especially for Test & Learn. With all the new changes, it is becoming increasingly clear that the Mastercard Way rules seems to apply only to those below a certain level. 
Promotion cycles have slowed down dramatically, and they provided a BS reason to justify it, and basically told us to suck it up. With no added benefits and increases lower than the inflation rate, people understandably don't see a reason to stay. They claim they have high standards for promotion when in fact most of my current managers don't seem to have those standards themselves. They started to tell us that meeting the progress score only "qualifies you for promotion, and doesn't guarantee it". The management also blamed its junior for expecting to be promoted within a timeframe because "they did not promise that when we joined". The culture is overall deteriorating with nothing to justify it, pay below industry for what the work requires. The management is looking to cut costs anywhere and everywhere, even at the expense of employees. It has also come to my attention that they reduced the cadence of employee surveys, and didn't share the full results of the ones they conducted. They praise themselves for being on the Best Employees list, when if fact MC is ranked #63 while Visa is #49, American Express is #4, and Capital One is #15.

review_text:
Acknowledge all contributions from teams and stop being focused on the favored few or you'll risk losing people who keep the ship sound and stable. New captains come in every few years but if the ship's already sunk, they'll have nowhere to sail from. 
Please stop the toxic favoritism, it's not productive to achieving results when a few take credit for all.
review_liked_text: Good opportunity to work with some smart and capable people around the world. Decent work life balance.
review_disliked_text:
The increasing favoritism in some teams has led to an extremely toxic work environment to the extent that colleagues not in the "favored few" live in a constant state of fear and dread. Ageism is also blatant for everyone below EVP , so don't plan to retire from here unless you make it to the top. 
Be prepared to manage up to get promoted - especially in IMC

review_disliked_text: I used to be proud to work at MC, felt like leaders listened to us. They no longer listen and RTO mandatory 3 days a week is ridiculous. You can apply for remote work but VPs always deny it. They have team agreements but the “team” is a department of 300+ people so the VP decides what days you come in office, you have no choice in the matter. Due to being less productive in office than at home, many people are working a standard of 10-12 hours per day

review_text:
Everyone is not cut out for leadership because they are good at their job. To be a leader the leader needs to pull out the best traits of their employees. Coach their employees to succeed, How is it a team with an I attitude?  I came across a director who did not want to help even though they knew my background and previous experience. I was hired in October and instantly saw another side of the person within the first week. 

From that point on it was just a terrible, toxic experience I would not wish on my worst enemy. I hope my immediate exit from this toxic environment displays the level of dissatisfaction with this company. The corporate structure and culture that's provided for outsiders is not welcoming at all. I would not recommend in my opinion, it is a bunch of outdated thinkers who are afraid of change or have been in corporate so long they do not think outside of the box.

review_liked_text: In my shore time at Mastercard I've made a career change and I've been supported along the way. I've made friends across the organization, and of course there's your rude egg every now and then, but there's a lot of great people. The benefits in my opinion are the best combination of benefits I've seen in my work experience. You're not going to get it all, but the mix of benefits aligns when where my focus is. Starting in 2024 the vacation benefits increased for everyone at the company, where prior to 2024 it was based all on tenure. Like I mentioned Mastercard isn't going to give you the whole kitchen sink, but they are listening and adjusting.
review_disliked_text: For me the open work environment can be difficult to focus, but not every office is the same or has converted to the open office setting.

review_text: Keep up the great work! Thank you for caring about us, the community and the world by setting the example of how to be a responsible company that can do great things while still making a successful and thriving business.
review_liked_text: 1. They treat you like adults. 2. The diverse culture is POSITIVE! You never hear that someone doesn't want to work today. The paid time off benefits are superlative. If you have a day you don't feel like working? Take a personal day with pay. You have plenty when you work here. 3. Advancement. If you don't grow here? You only have yourself to blame. Mastercard makes it a priority to help you grow and advance your career to whatever heights you seek. 4. Innovation. Have an idea? Awesome! Mastercard helps you bring it into fruition. You will have plenty of knowledgeable colleagues who want to help you along the way. 5. Make a difference. There are SO MANY ways to make a positive difference in your home, in your community and in the world here. Pick your preference. You'll have the best support system, you'll have the best cheerleaders and best LEADERS to help you.
review_disliked_text: You'll never want to leave. The flexible hours and flexible work from home option will make you work more. You'll WANT to, because Mastercard is so good to you.

review_liked_text:
- pay? (See below, all my pros devolve into cons)
- I work from home but they are steering away from this (so much for the new normal) and their handling of RTO has been a colossal mess
- I have (for now) an excellent manager and their manager is also great
- if you thrive in a dysfunctional environment and / or are better at compartmentalization than me, it might be fine
- some people like it (I did for a while)
review_disliked_text:
So many. 
- back to the subject of pay, like a lot of companies who expect not just to make a profit and keep up with inflation, but to make a higher profit, they expect *people* to put up with “merit” increases that do not keep up with inflation and are based on rigged performance reviews.
- In my area, there is little opportunity for upward mobility, especially if you don’t want to be a people manager. Getting a promotion is very difficult, and apparently doesn’t help your salary much. Part of the problem is that in my area of expertise, Mastercard is like twenty years behind, so unless our leadership catches up quick (not hopeful), there won’t be any new positions senior to what I have now. So as my uncle advised me twenty years ago, if you want to make what you’re worth, you have to switch jobs. 
- part of the reason for being so far behind I think is that they hire from within way too often. People float around from here to there, and are very impressed with how much they know about Mastercard, but meanwhile have no real experience in highly specialized areas. And they really like to tell people who do have years of actual experience how to do their job, and they get away with that and with actively interfering while not doing their own job. This is not a generalization based on one person. It’s been a pattern for a couple years across multiple teams and continues to this day
- hypocrisy. Supposedly decency is a part of “the Mastercard way” but, starting with the most egregious of several examples, an awful, high ranking person, who people complained about to HR, who oversaw at least two major initiatives that utterly failed, and who sowed so much chaos and dysfunction I’m not sure our department will recover anytime soon, was rewarded with a fellowship. As if that’s not bad enough, this was announced right after layoffs (very expensive layoffs based on severance figures) that were made over budget concerns. 
- these concerns have also contributed to an environment where continuing education is not deemed important. Also, programs that are critical to an organization that claims to be data driven are expected to either bring in revenue or show a direct correlation to it, even though their purpose is to reduce risk and provide critical functions for programs that do bring in revenue
- AI hype: our leadership is very confident in their knowledge of AI, but seems to be stuck in an echo chamber that excludes so many considerations I am hearing about everywhere else. I’m also not hearing much from talk here about the huge sustainability concerns around AI, it’s just full steam ahead, which does not match the internal and external claims of a commitment to sustainability
 - healthcare coverage is terrible, I’m paying way more that I ever have for less. The one consolation was a free telemedicine service. They switched providers though, without any regard for the quality of the new one. Surprise, it’s terrible. Is that decent?
- apparently my state has a loop hole that allows employers to get away with paying out fewer vacation days, so I am no longer given my full vacation balance at the beginning of the year, which means if (when) I leave, I’ll get paid off much less, if anything, compared to what I would have if I left at the same time last test last year. So they’re cutting back on benefits, and then there’s the meager pay increases, which means people’s actual compensation has *gone down*. Is that decent?

review_liked_text: work-life balance, great comp plan, flexible schedule, high vacation day policy

review_liked_text: Mastercard always value's your time and life outside of work. Never had an issue with taking time off for vacation/day appointments. Benefits are fantastic, and management has always treated me with respect, empathized when projects succeed or fail.
review_disliked_text: Mastercard's tech and engineering culture can be exhausting. Expect multi-year efforts for trivial engineering problems. Mastercard has a tendency to over-complicate, over-engineer solutions. It's a very process-driven company, not engineering driven. New technology, practices, or languages seldom gain traction.

review_liked_text: Good work life balance with good vacatio
review_disliked_text: A lot of issues with multiple teams involved in approvals

review_text: Reconsider pulling back on the flex life balance mandates. Understand the voices of the employees. Try not to pin this on the younger generation when they aren't the ones we should be solving for. This will lead to a high attrition rate come February/March.
review_liked_text: The company puts a lot of time and energy into Diversity and the environment.
review_disliked_text:
Mastercard has decided to take the company in a new direction in terms of their flexibility for the work/life balance. Up until now, the company has been rather flexible in letting employees determine which sort of hybrid schedule works best for them. This past week they've stated that as of January we will be 'expected' to do an 'average' of 3 days in office per week. The reasoning being to support the 'young' workers who we aren't being fair to. _x000D_
The young Gen Z population will be the first employees to jump ship to another company who will allow better remote/flex opportunities. _x000D_
_x000D_
#2 - Working 2 vs. 3 days in office as an example, provides no added benefit. Just because you are in the office more, does not ensure that more work is getting done, or that work related 'collaboration' is happening, or that there is any extra sense of urgency. _x000D_
_x000D_
#3 - Traveling to work extra days per week only takes away from productivity - most have commutes to the office, based on where the offices are located. So now you have to consider an extra 2-3 hours of sitting in your car, when you could be using those hours working remotely. A lot of teams are global, meaning that you aren't even sitting in the same office as many of your coworkers to begin with. _x000D_
_x000D_
#4 - The company is very invested in its environmental footprint with new ESG initiatives - however, adding more commuting days would seemingly add to carbon emissions output._x000D_
_x000D_
#5 - The company continues to profit quarter over quarter, with productivity at a high. And that was during the time where employees had been working off of their own schedule and working from where they feel is best for them in this new day and age. If a job can be done fully remotely, there shouldn't be a reason to require people back in the office 3 days a week, specifically.

review_text: Work on HR. Ensure they don't fire people on their birthdays. Ensure they consult the teams and bosses before firing people on their own. Ensure they check to see if the policies they're firing someone over are actually correct. Ensure they check the impact of firing someone (a team essential to the business just got blown up by them) before deciding not to remediate an issue and instead to fire immediately without warning.
review_liked_text: Great work/life balance. Good benefits. Some good people working there, and generally great opportunities to move careers within the company.
review_disliked_text: HR can abuse their power sometimes. The last one they did was to fire me. They conducted their own investigation, consulted no one, and then fired me (on my birthday). I've proven that their reasons were incorrect, but they just state "decision is final". My bosses found out via automated email later, and are freaking out as the team just got blown up. So be wary.

review_liked_text: Mastercard really does put their people first. They care about your mental wellbeing, they give you ample days off and time blocked off on your calendars to allow you to get caught up or take a break. They have a GREAT 401k program and an incredible learning academy that encourages you to expand your education. They stress putting yourself and family first and truly are very caring when any issues come up. They stress work life balance and I don't feel overworked or stressed. They also big on hiring from within, even if you don't have ALL of the experience, they are very eager to train. It is a very diverse company, which is wonderful and their pay is very competitive as well! Overall it is just a great place to work!

review_liked_text: Mastercard has high quality people and a good strategic technology vision. Full disclosure, giving low rating based on recent change is work from office policy. Otherwise would have been a very high rating.
review_disliked_text: Mastercard recently changed their work remote policy to being in the office 3 days a week. This is unfortunate as a lot of the resources that work here do not live close to the office due to the exorbitant cost of living near the New York City metropolitan area. Some of the best resources I work with have a commute of 1.5 to 2 hours. They’ve chosen to live in areas that are better suited for raising a family and more affordable to do so. Mastercard has some very high quality resources but they don’t pay near the top of the salary range for technology companies. While I think Mastercard is a great place to work for a lot of reasons it’s simply just not feasible that the vast majority can live within a reasonable commuting time of 30 minutes. I think it will only be a matter of time until some of these high quality resources find employment opportunities that offer a more flexible work arrangement. Speaking first hand the current policy seems to be working very well and I can attest that productivity is higher here than any other company I have worked at. I fear changing their policy will ultimately affect morale in a very negative way eventually leading to employee turnover. I don’t think 1.5 to 2 hour commute, 3 days a week is sustainable long term. I believe this decision will be an inflection point which will affect the company negatively. I anticipate the additional commuting time will affect the quality of the work being done as people will now have to concern themselves on how to absorb losing 3-4 hours of time a day or more (9-12 hours week). This decision is unfortunate and I think management should consider delaying this or possible reconsider something more flexible like 3 days once a month, two entire weeks a quarter, average of x amount of days per month. This decision feels like a rigid step backwards

review_liked_text: What impressed me most was Mastercard's dedication to fostering an inclusive and diverse workplace. The diversity of thought and culture among employees is one of the company's greatest strengths. They have numerous programs and initiatives to ensure that every voice is heard and valued, which created a welcoming and collaborative atmosphere. Work-life balance was also a priority at Mastercard. The company recognizes that happy, well-rested employees are more productive, and it shows in their flexible work arrangements and emphasis on well-being. The compensation was competitive, and there were ample opportunities for career growth and development. I benefited from various training programs and mentorship opportunities during my tenure, which helped me advance in my career.
review_disliked_text: At times, communication from top management about company direction and strategy can be unclear. This ambiguity can leave employees feeling disconnected from the broader company vision.

review_text: Keep up the great work! Looking forward to what MC accomplishes in the coming months and years.
review_liked_text: 1. A very diverse culture. 2. The PTO, benefits and salaries are very competitive. 3. They are a very innovative company taking your ideas and bringing them to fruition. 4. Lots of room for advancement, and managers are very supportive of development. 5. Lots of great opportunities for giving back to the community, surrounding areas and all over the world. 6. Flexible work schedules and work from home or anywhere options. I work from home several days a week, I am saving so much on gas and wear and tear on my car. Also, WFH helps with work life balance I am home when I could be sitting in traffic.
review_disliked_text: No cons in the 15 years I’ve worked here, MC has been amazing to me, hoping for another 15.

review_text: I am not the only person experiencing issues with our insurance. My advice for management would be to fix this issue, either by switching insurance companies for 2024 or by finding a better option for employees to communicate directly with the insurance company (Anthem).
review_liked_text: - Advancement and mentoring opportunities - Support from my manager - Good work/life balance - Great compensation - A great place to learn and grow in your career
review_disliked_text: The insurance offering changed in 2023 and is now a complete joke. Anthem is the provider and there is no way to get in touch with them directly. It is all through a third party (Accolade). That means if you have any account or coverage specific question, you need to go through Accolade. Which I don't even do anymore because they have given me incorrect information more than once. The submission process for out of network claims is unclear. If you do submit, you won't even know if it was accepted/denied until at minimum four weeks later. With the previous insurance, it took half the time and your reimbursement arrived maximum 17 days later. I still have not received an answer from Anthem after escalating this to HR. It has been over a month since initially contacting. This is unacceptable. If you regularly see a healthcare provider, beware.

review_liked_text: Working at MasterCard is an incredible opportunity!! The company's commitment to innovation, global reach, and ethical business practices is truly inspiring. The chance to collaborate with talented professionals from diverse backgrounds, make a positive impact on financial inclusion, and contribute to the advancement of secure and convenient payment solutions.
review_disliked_text: While there are many advantages to working at MasterCard, it's important to consider some potential drawbacks as well. One potential con could be the fast-paced and demanding nature of the financial industry, which may require high levels of dedication and commitment. Additionally, like any large organization, there may be some hierarchical structures that could impact decision-making or hinder flexibility. Lastly, the global nature of MasterCard's operations may involve occasional travel or working across different time zones, which could potentially pose challenges for work-life balance. These cons may vary depending on individual preferences and priorities.

review_liked_text: The aim is to bring data processing and storage closer to the place of data creation in order process the large data load as quickly as possible and to get latency problems under control. Edge computing is often the prerequisite for applications to be provide data in real time at ant given location. Instead of relying on a central cloud data center, sometimes thousands of kilometers away, companies want to process locally generated mass data. Such as those generated by mobile devices or the often-countless machines integrated into an lot network, on site. In combination with 5G mobile communications and wifi-6 networks, edge computing enables fast on-site processing. With Next Edge, Mastercard is responding to this trend and has developed and event- driven framework that can handle workloads at the edge.

review_text: Please correct retaliation from those in senior management in ONE. I did the right thing and reported ethical and professional misconduct, and was fired after 8 years because I spoke up about ethical and professional concerns. Get rid of nepotism and George Maddaloni.
review_liked_text: Mastercard’s benefits, opportunities to advance, ability to be flexible to employee needs, focus on implementing new technologies, and the strong product focus makes working at the company enjoyable and keeps things interesting. It’s a great way to learn and advance. I was there for 8 years in various roles. I enjoyed the vision and culture under Ajay Banga’s leadership greatly, and was sad to see him leave.
review_disliked_text: The cons of working at Mastercard are the politics and bureaucracy in the Operations, Networking , and Employee Digital Experience (ONE) organization. The ONE organization has poor executive leadership that has a culture of nepotism/cliques and corporate bullying. My last few months, people who reported misconduct or disagreed with the CTO were put on a list and their jobs eliminated. Don’t report anything to HR or ethics - they are not your friend. There is a lack of training, and when large transformation efforts are rolled out, people are expected to learn on their own - they roll things out or start initiatives without much consideration for adoption and change management with their employees. I self taught and spent time trying to educate senior leadership to understand the impact - they expect a check mark and don’t really value the mindset of exemplifying change from the top. There is no work-life balance - I was working between 60-80 hours and wearing multiple hats. When I spoke up, and set boundaries, my manager’s behavior changed and I felt I had a target on my back in every meeting. There is a strong lack of company appreciation around employees. Some managers are good at recognition, but most not so much, especially senior leaders. There is a strong focus on meeting objectives without regard and reward for people going the extra mile. There is a lack of accountability culture, and when you hold peers accountable for the responsibility they signed up, they get offended and hate you. Coworkers like to throw people under the bus, and if you are a manager don’t share anything with your peers or direct reports - there is a gossip culture and people will do anything to get ahead. For women in tech, if you are assertive and just doing your job, good luck advancing as you will be painted like a villain while your male colleagues can get away with unprofessional behavior.

review_text:
- Stop treating employees like cattle_x000D_
- The highest levels of executive management need to go.  As is typical in publicly traded companies, the executives care more about shareholders than employees._x000D_
- Implement a nepotism policy and actually *enforce* it.  Get rid of the "good ol' boy" network.
review_liked_text:
- This company has a lot of great talent.  I know a ton of truly smart people who work hard and deliver value every day._x000D_
- This company is truly diverse.  It's has a very accepting culture.  Mastercard celebrates women, people of color, and the LGBTQ community incredibly well._x000D_
- The company encourages movement internally.  If you don't like your job, chances are you can move to another team with ease._x000D_
- The compensation and benefits packages are truly stellar.  Salaries are very good.  The 401k match is phenomenal.  You get lots of paid time off.  There are great health plans.
review_disliked_text:
- The CEO practices "good ol' boy" politics.  We built an entire tech hub in Pune to outsource tons of jobs because that's the CEO's home town._x000D_
- The work/life balance is not very good at times.  Extra hours are the norm for a lot of people._x000D_
- Resources are often very limited while demands remain high.  We're constantly pressured to "do more with less."  That usually means: work more hours instead of hiring more people._x000D_
- The new president of O&T (Ed McLaughlin)_x000D_
- The office is being actively remodeled into an open floorplan, with no walls.  People literally work elbow-to-elbow with the person next to them.  There is no privacy.  There is no personal space._x000D_
- Certain members of executive management employ bullying tactics (often yelling and screaming inappropriately in meetings) with no recourse.

review_text: The main reason people are still around is because of the great people that joined a cool company called APT. As those people keep getting frustrated and leaving, more will follow. The other big reason is contractual obligations, such as sign-on bonus return, 401k vesting, etc that were put into place to stop people from leaving once things went south. If you want any hope of maintaining what world class talent remains, reverting many of the horrendous new policies would be a first step.
review_liked_text:
- Lots of great (world class talent) people still left...for now_x000D_
- Decently flexible with hours_x000D_
- Base compensation
review_disliked_text:
- The company is dead. It got consumed by Mastercard, which doesn't know anything about engineering or engineers_x000D_
- New benefits are completely non competitive_x000D_
_x000D_
There is no Applied Predictive Technologies. Mastercard kept the name, culture, and policies around just long enough to get through recruitment season and gobble up as much great talent as they could - by using current employees to recruit heavily to a company that wouldn't exist shortly after offers were accepted.  I feel horrible about what I have done on behalf of the company lying to so many students, even if I fully believed all the great things I said during recruitment season. We didn't know better and recruited based on working with world class talent, a small agile team, flat structure, great benefits, collegiate atmosphere and culture, etc. All of these things have been swept away before those hires will join. _x000D_
Nearly every time I talk to co-workers outside of work (or even in the office in hushed tones) it is about exit plans and mourning the loss of the company we once loved to work at.

review_text: Keep creating opportunities for employees to take calculated risks and challenge the status quo.  Invest in great developers.  A technology company needs great strategic minds and the developers who can actually put the vision into action.
review_liked_text: MasterCard under the leadership of Ajay Banga is trying to be a payments technology innovator and leader.  This vision is working, as evidenced by amazing stock growth.  Many of the newer people that they have hired are go-getters with great backgrounds who will work tirelessly to fulfill this vision.  I enjoyed my years at this company and learned lots from very smart co-workers who came from McKinsey and BCG as well as Silicon Valley startups.  The company is innovative and fairly nimble given its size.  It was a pleasure to work there (most of the time) and I would probably go back for the right opportunity.
review_disliked_text: Beware of people who have been at the company more than 10 years.  There are lots of them.  These people are "old school MasterCard."  They are not particularly innovative or aggressive, and they have little to no desire to find new ways to solve problems.  They clock in and clock out, collecting a decent salary and bonus.  They live nearby and like having an easy commute and treat their roles like a 9 to 5 country club.  Mr. Banga seems to be aware of these leeches and slowly but surely a few of them get laid off each year.  Just don't make the mistake of working for one of them.  It will just take you that much longer to get where you need to be.  This happened to me, twice, and therefore I moved on.

review_liked_text: Mastercard cares about its employees. They actually listen to each of us no matter what position someone holds. Your career means something to management because its philosophy is individual's make the whole what it is. I will never regret leaving where I came from to be a part of this amazing company.

review_disliked_text:
Great compensation package and benefits (this is holding many untalented people from leaving the company). CEO is hiring all of his college buddies and kicking others out. _x000D_
_x000D_
If you are in technology and work at any site other than ST. Louis it's a career suicide. It's is either St. Louis way or no way. The people in STL office have strong bond to support each other. (Unusual amount of married couple work here, which creates this support structure). They work like federal government agency, really slow and bound by complicated processes to ensure slow progress. This makes talented people in other offices to either leave or pushed out. There is no voice for them. Top technology executives positions should be moved to Purchase to align closely to business. This is the only technology company which prevents new development because of policies. Hopefully decentralization vision would help. They tout it's a technology company but still act as if it is a financial company. _x000D_
_x000D_
Scooters and foosball tables are not the only things that makes Google and Facebook cool, those companies are run by young people with vision not by some vacuum tube programmer from the 40s. _x000D_
_x000D_
There are unlimited layers of management, many of the middle management people are waiting for retirement, so they are reluctant to change and risk. They need to be kicked out to make any positive outcomes. There is huge disconnect between executive management and the people managers in between who care about their jobs more than progress of the company.

review_text: You guys do a great job making Mastercard a great place to work but your processes are terrible.
review_liked_text: The company is amazing for work-life balance, the pay was great. and you get a lot of freedom and management welcomes your thoughts and ideas. The people I worked with were great and we had a very diverse workforce with people from all over the world.
review_disliked_text: Ok the bad. While this is a great place to work over time the amount of bureaucracy just gets tiring. The way this place is organized is just insane with every group doing its own thing and every group having different rules to engage them. More than once I'd have a product ready but it could take months to get time from other teams to do their parts all the while I'm sitting in my status meeting rehashing the same stuff. waiting. Next, they are in a terrible position of trying to embrace modern processes for IT but desperately clinging to old processes that should have been let go years ago. They do innovate but also horde every legacy idea and it's a maze trying to wind through all that. There is also a bad habit of knee-jerk reactions to every little issue. Instead of letting us sit down and build a solution we were constantly tasked with patching up or slapping on another monitoring tool. And that comment about management welcoming your thoughts from the Pros? The line managers do but while you are entering it into the backlog they also will tell you it's going to sit there for years.

review_liked_text: Rewards hard work and focuses on performance over years of experience.
review_disliked_text: Large company atmosphere with 30,000 employees

review_text:
Drive out costs now when we can do it with deliberate focus; if we wait it will only be painful later._x000D_
_x000D_
Hire for intelligence, integrity and motivation, we have enough people who worked in industry for 10 years, we need some more young people with a sharp mind and fire in their belly._x000D_
_x000D_
Formalize the career development model, encourage telecommuting and clarify roles and responsibilities._x000D_
_x000D_
Finally, whoever is designing and implementing the leadership development program is failing and it is such an important factor. You need to mobilize the entire top 4 layers to learn and apply strong leadership skills._x000D_
_x000D_
And you also need to stop hiring jerks - hire emotionally aware, competent and intelligent people to start displacing the lousy people managers you have at the mid to upper levels.
review_liked_text: Market position and industry outlook is great. Overall compensation package is designed to encourage long-term commitment. Brand is phenomenal around the globe. Upside market opportunity in the payments space is enviable. Company's financial strength and scalability is admirable.
review_disliked_text: MasterCard hires for job experience in industry, specifically banking. So you have alot of people who come to the table with fairly large egos and limited creativity. Large level of political drama to deal with. The company moves very slow - not responsive to clients, missed deadlines are common practice, 9:30 to 5:00 sharp are standard hours so if you're an eager eddie you'll be disappointed. Basic management discipline is missing. You will also be frustrated by the highest level of bureaucracy covering the company's use of data and information. It is an obsession that prevents us from getting things done and having an impact with clients.

review_text: Keep hiring great people!
review_liked_text:
People: From the bottom to the top, the people at APT are awesome to interact with. I'm lucky to call many of my coworkers friends even after they move on to other opportunities. The amount of time APT devotes to employee growth is phenomenal._x000D_
_x000D_
Flexibility: If you do a good job, APT will bend over backwards to keep you at APT. That has taken many flavors including office flexibility (even overseas), trying out different roles within the company, and new roles altogether. This has gotten unexpectedly better after joining Mastercard. _x000D_
_x000D_
Interesting Problems: Beyond helping clients with testing and evaluating new business ideas, there are tons of new market opportunities that give employees the opportunity to learn new things and help shape the path of the company. From new verticals, new products, or internal projects, you will never be bored. _x000D_
_x000D_
Benefits: Tons of free snacks/food/team events, top technology, plenty of vacation days, volunteer days, 401(k) match is crazy good.
review_disliked_text:
Unpredictable workload: Since folks are staffed on multiple teams, there is always work to be done somewhere. In client services you can be at the mercy of your client who might have an urgent request that throws a wrench into your evening (or weekend) plans. In general people know when the work is going to be busier, but you can be blindsided especially when all of your clients are busy at the same time. _x000D_
_x000D_
Health insurance: Only disappointment of the current benefits package. Maybe employees were spoiled before Mastercard, but the health insurance plan has taken a big step back. It is not competitive with other tech companies or top tier consulting firms.

review_text:
Place more value on people management skills. 
Reduce the politics and replace it with hard metrics and facts.
review_liked_text: Mastercard is good for people who want to coast in a job for 5-10 years or more. The work life balance is great because expectations are minimal and people move slowly.
review_disliked_text:
The company is not set up for career progression. There are tons of people who have been at the company 10+ years and coast in mid-level management. This creates a stagnant environment where you can't learn from teammates and there is limited innovation. In general, people operate in the mindset of "it's not my job." 

Promotions are slow (about 2-3 years for Manager level and below; 3-5 years for Director level; and sometimes longer for Vice Presidents). There is no clear promotion criteria and no formal system for annual career reviews. For example, your manager writes a ~2 paragraph performance review once a year but they're not required to collect 360 feedback from your colleagues. There's also no opportunity to give upward feedback to your manager. 

Like many big organizations, Mastercard is highly political. As a result, senior leadership can be hit or miss. Many SVPs are figureheads that don't know their business well and don't have the expertise to support their team. Leaders are not rewarded for good management; rather, they are rewarded for executive visibility. It's all about who you know and how well you can sell an idea (versus actually achieving a goal).

review_text: Look to promote especially when you have a lower level worker constantly helping and teaching the higher level workers

review_text: Women in IT and leadership is very important and a great idea, however do not dilute standards to promote women to just appease CEO and achieve 50% leadership parity. Shuffle Executives from their comfort zones to take on new challenges and make decisive changes to build next generation products. Promote people who challenge the status quo and ready to confront leadership for the benefit of the company. Finally, put the decency values to real practice within Technology organization.
review_liked_text: Good CEO vision, corporate strategy, and business model.  Mastercard has a competitive product strategy to win the market share globally.  They offer very nice benefits. CEO has outlined good cultural values on paper and genuinely expects everyone to live by them. In summary, a good place to work outside Technology department.
review_disliked_text: Technology organization is all about EVPs driving their own agenda and promoting people based on affinity and punishing those that challenge them with decency. Her way/his way mentality results in picking people and strategies to just exercise power. Some Executives are living in their comfort zone for a long time creating risks to the core areas of the company with poor technical oversight. New leaders are busy copying other tech companies creating more silos. It's not uncommon where Executives use performance management as a tool for employee retaliation. President has a good vision but mostly surrounded by poor leadership team resulting in slow technology advancements.

review_liked_text: The ease and ability to Work remote
review_disliked_text: Management is overbearing and the pay isn’t up to the competitors

review_text:
The executive management leads who report to the CEO need to:_x000D_
- Stick to their decisions;_x000D_
- Prioritize their strategic imperatives per business unit and region._x000D_
_x000D_
They should take a page from the CEO who is very clear and sticks to his priorities and decisions.  One comment on the CEO is he likes to be right and goes off gut feel at times.  But overall, he's taking MasterCard in the right direction for the most part.
review_liked_text:
- Almost bulletproof, revenue-generating business model_x000D_
- Strong brand built from the strength of its distribution, products, and the "Priceless" campaign_x000D_
- Global company_x000D_
- Seasoned, competent executive management_x000D_
- A lot more entrepreneurial than it gets credit for_x000D_
- Work-life balance_x000D_
- Cool office for a Fortune 500 company_x000D_
- Getting better at horizontal structure
review_disliked_text:
- Its business model, which is an open loop, makes it difficult to move fast since its dependent on issuers and merchants_x000D_
- Hasn't yet earned credit for being a "technology" company within financial services_x000D_
- Silos galore: functionally and geographically_x000D_
- Executive management needs to narrow down its priorities since there are too many_x000D_
- Although only just over 7,000 employees globally, it operates like a 700,000-person organization at times_x000D_
- Some departments are becoming more intense -- lessening the work-life balance -- because of questionable strategic decisions _x000D_
- Can't expect morale to increase just because of adding a pool and ping-pong table (they are nice additions) -- needs to be truly authentic_x000D_
- High performers in middle management can be "stuck" because of the top-heavy organizational structure, coupled the company's above average retention rates

review_text: Keep up the company culture through rapid growth and change! Let's figure out what the pros are of being small, and hold on to those as we quickly grow in size.
review_liked_text:
APT has a great working environmental for young professionals; the culture is entrepreneurial and 'techie' with a hint of corporate professionalism for good measure._x000D_
_x000D_
The work we do at APT is VERY practical and affects the real-world. I love walking into my clients' stores and observing my surroundings to see what test cell they are in for various initiatives they are running!_x000D_
_x000D_
Because of APT's size, the feedback cycle is excellent. As an employee approaching my second year, I get to gather recurring feedback from managers, principals, and VPs on strengths and development opportunities._x000D_
_x000D_
Working hours at APT are quite flexible. Employees have tasks assigned by various teams, and it is up to the employee to choose how and when to meet those deadlines. If you like getting your day started at 7am, go for it, if you'd rather stroll in at 10am, go for it (just get your work done on time!)
review_disliked_text:
Hours. Like most consulting firms, APT is not a 9-5 job. Hours can be long at times, especially when a readout of an analysis is around the corner._x000D_
_x000D_
Size (sometimes). Because of our size (~50 employees in San Francisco office), we still have tasks such as 'kitchen duty'. While very start-up-like, I'd prefer not to have a task on my calendar telling me it's my day to run the dishwasher this week. This may change soon as we continue to grow.

review_text:
- keep supporting & taking care of your people, and we will take care of the company_x000D_
- create/make more time for purposeful innovation; I wish I had more time for it; my best innovations are done in the middle of the night; on my own time._x000D_
- continue diversifying the teams; there's still some 'hubris' among us
review_liked_text: Doing good by doing well initiatives; commitment to diversity, inclusion, social impact. The senior leadership walks the walk and lives by example. I work on one of the most diverse teams, both in terms of culture, background, origin, professional experience, tech & non-tech, short-term and long-term thinkers. Have had an opportunity to explore new technology, work with a lot of start-ups, and work on long-term projects that can have a big impact on the company 5-10-15 years from now. Phenomenal team culture and camaraderie. The company's response to Covid-19 + inequality is something that I am tremendously proud of. As well as it's commitment to privacy, security, user-centricity. You can find challenging assignments here and find others who are interested in solving problems. I continue learning and experimenting every day! Absolutely phenomenal people to work with. Mastercard is a place/company to be proud of.
review_disliked_text: Team camaraderie can vary across teams (as in any place). Rarely, but you can sometimes run into people who believe Mastercard is untouchable in terms of its competitive moat, whereas we need to be bold and willing to disrupt from within (and a lot of teams already do!).

review_liked_text: Great place to work. Great flexibility.
review_disliked_text: No cons that I can think of

review_text: practice what Ajay and Ed preach.
review_liked_text: Development and growth opportunities, truly global company with more opportunities for those who want to see the world, a CEO with his head on right, and the new President of Ops & Technology is a man of vision.  The people are mostly excellent individuals, but some in the United States resent their global counterparts.  5 days of paid time to volunteer in your community!  They preach diversity and inclusion, and for those willing to go above and beyond, countless opportunities to get involved in something you enjoy and make a difference.  Total compensation package is very solid but base salary is lower than market.  Most lines of business are open to ideas.  The technology hubs in Saint Louis has a reputation in the area for being a sweat shop.
review_disliked_text: Work-Life balance is a problem, exagerated depending on the organization or line of business.  Avoid Operations or project management work if you want to work less than 60 hours a week.  The culture is at odds with itself, with cumbersome and frustrating processes and politics.  Some senior and VP management have a style of compliance (my way or the highway) and do not want questions or input, and they make bad decisions at conflict with official Corporate strategy.  There is a culture of blame when something goes wrong, and people are busy protecting themselves rather than solutions.
