review_text: In general, keep doing what you're doing! Make sure we maintain our excellent culture even as we become more integrated within Mastercard.
review_liked_text:
Impact - the work  we do every day has a tangible impact on our clients.  Our clients treat us as trusted partners, and as a result I feel personally invested in helping my clients succeed._x000D_
_x000D_
Career growth - Since APT is growing so quickly, promotion tracks are quick and every year the role changes significantly. Employees at APT are able to get management experience much quicker than at other organizations._x000D_
_x000D_
People - the people at APT are incredibly smart, hard working and humble. Given that the job is so team-based, being able to work with incredible people every day makes the job more enjoyable._x000D_
_x000D_
Lifestyle - while the hours in client services are not 40 hours/week, they are not nearly as high as the rest of the consulting industry.  Travel exists but is minimal, which keeps the work exciting without being overwhelming. _x000D_
_x000D_
Comp/Benefits - excellent; likely best in class._x000D_
_x000D_
Senior management - employees are encouraged to provide firm feedback every six months, which senior management actively reads and addresses. Senior management seems to genuinely care about keeping employees happy.
review_disliked_text: Working on multiple teams at the same time can lead to longer hours at times, but can be mitigated with diligent time management.

review_liked_text: - Reasonable hours - Great office - Good team
review_disliked_text: - Big Corporate work flows

review_text: Stop the blatant favoritism and create a culture of professionalism and fairness.  Give everyone a chance.
review_liked_text: Nice HQ facilities and amenities.  Located in beautiful Purchase, NY.    Great pay and benefits.  Interesting people to work with and diversity is prevalent.
review_disliked_text: Only the selected few are successful at MC. Org. structure has too many layers of middle management (SBLs and Group Heads) who are out of touch with the needs and issues of the company.  Processes and systems are very backward, and it takes forever to get anything done.  Too much politics and favoritism - it appears a core group of people are recycled or moved around and giving opportunities to advance their career.  The culture is one of fear and retaliation resulting in a complacent attitude and fear of making changes or improvements.  The company is constantly laying off and reorganizing without any future goal in mind.  This creates a culture of chaos and constant upheaval not to mention the low moral it creates among the employees.  Fire drill demands and unrealistic workloads are an everyday occurrence.  Oh I can go on... but I'll stop here.

review_liked_text: Buenos beneficios y life-work balanced
review_disliked_text: pago menor en comparación a otras consultoras

review_liked_text: Great employee relations and compensation.
review_disliked_text: Extremely matrixed and global organization.

review_text: Purge management from the top down.
review_liked_text: On site gym in the building.
review_disliked_text: 1. Long hours with little reward 2. Management does not have much technical depth 3. Passive aggressive culture

review_text:
Take a hard look at the people who have been here for 20+ years and ask yourself if they are here because they are bright & talented or because they have learned how to work the system and are not willing to work as hard as they would have to if they were to start someplace new.  Better yet, COULD they get another job?  Would you hire them now if they weren't already part of the organization?_x000D_
_x000D_
We will never take the lead if our managers are from an old school network and are setting the tone of how things are done here - processes that are 20+ years old are not going to bring us to the top.
review_liked_text:
Work/life balance_x000D_
Great commute for those living in Westchester
review_disliked_text:
Too many people have been here forever who are set in their ways and unwilling to allow innovative thinking._x000D_
If someone sticks around long enough they become a manager - even if they are not qualified._x000D_
Newcomers are not made to feel welcome by people who have been here for a long time._x000D_
Having worked in other large companies, the talent at MC does not compare.  People stay here because they can't go anywhere else!_x000D_
Not a place for people who are driven.

review_text: Too many silos. Every group has become so rigid about taking on work that they should take on, that no one will budge on anything. It takes several groups passing things back and forth to get the smallest thing accomplished. Ridiculous number of meetings each day. By the time you get through all of the meetings your brain is fried, makes it hard to get anything done.
review_liked_text: MasterCard definitely cares about its employees. During the pandemic it was clear the upper management was doing as much as they could to make things easier on the rank and file. Overall, pretty good benefits. Good timeoff policy. I genuinely love and recommend the company. But if you chose to work there, you will work a lot.
review_disliked_text: In a lot of ways, as mastercard got bigger, it has become impossible to get anything accomplished without massive red tape. You spend a lot of time banging your head against the wall. The people at mastercard are generally really good people. And I love the company. But there is too much work to do, and you go in every morning knowing that to get the littlest thing done will probably be excruciating.

review_text: pretend - just pretend - like surface-level benefits arent "good enough"
review_liked_text: 401K, good for family folks
review_disliked_text: corp finance is not pleasant at this co. through and through

review_liked_text: bonus and 401k are good.
review_disliked_text: turnover is an issue. everyone is under great stress.

review_text:
Take a hard look at the people who have been here for 20+ years and ask yourself if they are here because they are bright & talented or because they have learned how to work the system and are not willing to work as hard as they would have to if they were to start someplace new.  Better yet, COULD they get another job?  Would you hire them now if they weren't already part of the organization?_x000D_
_x000D_
We will never take the lead if our managers are from an old school network and are setting the tone of how things are done here - processes that are 20+ years old are not going to bring us to the top.
review_liked_text:
Work/life balance_x000D_
Great commute for those living in Westchester
review_disliked_text:
Too many people have been here forever who are set in their ways and unwilling to allow innovative thinking._x000D_
If someone sticks around long enough they become a manager - even if they are not qualified._x000D_
Newcomers are not made to feel welcome by people who have been here for a long time._x000D_
Having worked in other large companies, the talent at MC does not compare.  People stay here because they can't go anywhere else!_x000D_
Not a place for people who are driven.

review_text: Too many silos. Every group has become so rigid about taking on work that they should take on, that no one will budge on anything. It takes several groups passing things back and forth to get the smallest thing accomplished. Ridiculous number of meetings each day. By the time you get through all of the meetings your brain is fried, makes it hard to get anything done.
review_liked_text: MasterCard definitely cares about its employees. During the pandemic it was clear the upper management was doing as much as they could to make things easier on the rank and file. Overall, pretty good benefits. Good timeoff policy. I genuinely love and recommend the company. But if you chose to work there, you will work a lot.
review_disliked_text: In a lot of ways, as mastercard got bigger, it has become impossible to get anything accomplished without massive red tape. You spend a lot of time banging your head against the wall. The people at mastercard are generally really good people. And I love the company. But there is too much work to do, and you go in every morning knowing that to get the littlest thing done will probably be excruciating.

review_text: pretend - just pretend - like surface-level benefits arent "good enough"
review_liked_text: 401K, good for family folks
review_disliked_text: corp finance is not pleasant at this co. through and through

review_liked_text: bonus and 401k are good.
review_disliked_text: turnover is an issue. everyone is under great stress.

review_text: Keep up the great work!
review_liked_text:
I love the people I work with at APT. Everyone is extremely smart and hard working, yet humble and inclusive. That is not a combination found in many places. I love the teams I work with and the challenging projects we work on together. _x000D_
_x000D_
Since APT is a small-medium sized company, young people are given a ton of ownership early on. This can be extremely overwhelming, but equally as rewarding. My advisers and mentors are always challenging me to grow professionally, and my teammates help keep each other accountable with both personal and professional goals. _x000D_
_x000D_
Other perks, the office always has free food and we have so many exciting events going on! (For example, my social "house" - similar to Harry Potter houses - is having an ice cream social today!) I love the young, relaxed, and fun culture. _x000D_
_x000D_
Pay is competitive... especially if you're fresh out of college with minimal skill sets :)
review_disliked_text:
The MasterCard acquisition has brought with it some changes to our benefits. Healthcare offer got worse, and the way we manage expenses has gotten more stringent. _x000D_
_x000D_
Work life balance for client services is tough... I work in product development where the work life balance is much more manageable

review_text:
New executive leadership damaging the mastercard brand and culture. Mastercard itself is a brand. It cannot follow the culture of Amazon. We are not in eCommerce business infect we enable eCommerce merchant. _x000D_
Don't copy job families of Amazon. Learn what we've good in mastercard instead of emphasizing what new executives and leadership hired from Amazon know._x000D_
Don't wait for one more negative pulse survey feedback.
review_liked_text:
Good work life balance_x000D_
Good pay scale_x000D_
Talented Peers and Co-workers
review_disliked_text:
Leadership and executives fired from Amazon joining the mastercard at higher level. They are playing dirty politics and resource poaching. Better join Amazon instead of mastercard._x000D_
Executive joined from amazon has not shown any result in first 9 months. _x000D_
Emphasizes on Bell-curve _x000D_
All Managers are being forced to identify average performer and fire them at year end._x000D_
Wrong commitments of raise the bar being executed wrongly._x000D_
Old mastercard employees being cornered to make place to hire professionals from Amazon._x000D_
Emphasizes on Cloud Native instead of focusing more on AI and Machine Learning._x000D_
I recommended to friend first try to Amazon if you won't get selected then try in mastercard.

review_text: Don't feel threatened when you are looked in the eye and spoken to.  If something was not done to your satisfaction, communicate it or provide criticism/feedback.
review_liked_text: I was a contractor for an associate software engineer position for $25/hr.  I was paid on time.  You work a lot more than you are paid for, but it is very nice to work with such a large organization.  It is a big place.  I am sure there are some good teams there.
review_disliked_text: The details of the job were hidden behind senior employee's egos.  I was constantly reminded that I was a contractor and not an employee.  There was an enormous lack of communication.  I was constantly being cussed at and berated.  I guess management was constantly overworked.  There was a lot of negative gossip initiated by management.  Obviously, you work hard and feel good about your work and are let down when after looking people in the eye day in and day out and dealing with a lot of nonsense you receive a call from a contract representative you've met once saying you are no longer employed.  A lot of micromanagement.

review_text: Stop being so risk adverse and allowing HR and Legal to run the business.   Create better coordination by revising the incentive structure and individual objectives.
review_liked_text:
When I thought about joining MasterCard, I had reservations.  It appeared to be a good place to go if you had decided you wanted to coast along, and do a minimal amount of work.  But my interview, and my subsequent job experience proved otherwise._x000D_
_x000D_
MasterCard is full of bright people, who are energetic and know the industry.  With rare exception, I was impressed by the people I met, their backgrounds and the competency they brought to the tasks at hand._x000D_
_x000D_
_x000D_
For people who are interested in the payments space, it's a great place to work.
review_disliked_text:
On the other hand, I would say that MasterCard is unnecessarily bureaucratic for an organization of its size.  Because of the incentive system and other factors, there's a lot of turf battles, less than needed coordination, and inefficiencies.  However, there is a concerted effort (and there has been for many years) to change that.  _x000D_
_x000D_
The IPO appeared to also change how the business was run--more risk adversion, more of a short term focus, more attention to boosting the daily stock price.

review_text: Work hard to know the folks at the bottom - they are the company's future leaders and APT is growing so fast it's hard to stay connected to leadership and across teams.
review_liked_text: APT hires incredible people.  The staff here is ridiculously intelligent, diverse and very easy to work with.  The culture encourages intellectual honesty, frank communication, hard work and collaboration.  The structure provides opportunities for career growth, professional mentorship, and a variety of ways to be involved with and contribute to the firm.  I've never worked somewhere with so many good people at every level.  From office administrator to CEO - this place is full of genuinely decent, incredibly talented people.
review_disliked_text: There is nothing laid back, easy or comfortable about being in an office full of over-achievers.  You have to hussle here, or you stand out like a sore thumb.  Expectations are high, there's a lot of work to be done, and everyone is 10 steps ahead already.  This is a great place to grow and learn, but only if you're willing to put in best effort and bring your A-game every day.

review_text: Try some loyalty to folks that built the company and don't be so greedy at the top - how rich do you need to get at the top???  When your stack has grown 100000% do you really need to fire everyone over 45 because kids are cheaper???
review_liked_text: Spent most of my career there - was a very rewarding place you could do interesting work and with smart people in a great industry - then typical corporate greed set in and it was out with the old - MAJOR age discriminator - All the money goes to the top 5 people and they will fire anyone over 45 making good money to replace them with a green college grad or newly minted MBA
review_disliked_text: Not the place it once was  --  from a business perspective they are cooking - but from an ethical and employee perspective they are scum bags

review_text: Continue to maintain APT's strong, independent culture, and work to promote an emphasis on work/life balance from the top down.
review_liked_text:
APT is full of brilliant, hard-working, and helpful people that care about your professional development and the company's success. Even as it has grown rapidly and was acquired by Mastercard last year, it has retained an energetic, young culture that feels not far from its start-up roots. While it may sound cliche, a good idea is treated as such regardless of the level of seniority that it comes from._x000D_
_x000D_
APT quickly gives you a great deal of responsibility and enables you to make impactful contributions within your first year. It is a challenging, fast-paced environment that allows you to grow quickly and develop expertise. APT is a great place to start your career.
review_disliked_text:
With excellent compensation, lots of responsibility, and challenging work comes long hours. APT is not a 9-5 environment. At times, it can be difficult to maintain a good work/life balance._x000D_
_x000D_
APT's fundamental mission (applying the principles of experimentation to solve complex business challenges) is very compelling and differentiated, but the end applications of it can be less interesting at times.

review_text:
Consider spending a little more money on simple technology enhancements that support day to day operations, in the long run employees will be more effecient (saving money) and customers will be happier.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Employees still feel that they have no place to go in fear of retaliation.  HR recently sat on a phone call un-announced for an hour; very sneaky.  I have no trust in the process or the department. _x000D_
_x000D_
Consider implementing a process for escalating business decisions that are "stuck in the mud" with their existing management.
review_liked_text: The life-work balance is wonderful.  Everyone pulls together to make things happen and we all take personal pride in quality work.  Quality work is usually compenstated for in multiple ways. Truly a global company.
review_disliked_text: Upper level management changes too frequently, causing confusion and lack of consistency.  Probably like most companies there are some bad seeds in the group that talk out of both sides of their mouth, play favorites and are in it for themselves.  NY employees are not flexible in the culturaly differences. Too many opinions and performance reviews based on hear say.

review_text: Give those who have 50-60% of the experience, but have good business acumen, the chance to try a new role. Don't give it all to the YoPros. I wish I was able to move more side to side in order to move up. It's their loss.
review_liked_text: The best part was working with all of the diverse people. I got exposure to a true global environment and as such, have learned a lot from my peers. Ajay Banga turned the company around around three years ago, positioning MasterCard as a technology company vs a financial services company. Yes, it's payments, but without the technology, transactions cannot happen. I also have the utmost respect for Ron Garrow, the Head of HR. He is the most approachable person in the C-Suite. He always says hello and stops and listens. He is genuine.
review_disliked_text: There was absolutely no career path for me. Unfortunately, when I thought I had it, there were changes. Wish I could have stayed on longer, but when you see there is no future, it is time to move on.

review_text: Too many MBA's are managing tech people. You are losing great people because of the egos of managers who considered themselves heir to the throne.  There is no real avenue for an employee to complain. Most people keep their heads down and collect paychecks instead of bucking the system.
review_liked_text: Pay is typically above average. Great Bonus. The overall brand is stellar.  Good job if you are a yes-man or yes-woman and can put up with a large work load and be able to take the blame for dropping the ball while performing miracles.
review_disliked_text: Management rotations and constant team splitting and merging.  Health Insurance going to High Deductible Plan as only offering. Too much time is spent on attracting millenials with gimmicks like scooters and arcade games. They want to be a tech company but management and the employee review process is structured not like a tech company, it is rigid and used as fodder to abuse those that question management.

review_text: Management should continue to invest in ways to improve work-life balance for consultants. I know they are already investing a lot of resources, but I want to encourage them to continue doing so.
review_liked_text: I have stayed at APT for 5+ years because of the people, the work, and the opportunities to grow. First and foremost, everyone I work with is great to work with and wants each other to succeed. I also really enjoy the work we do and the variety of industries I get exposed to by working on 10+ clients at once. Lastly, even though we are a much bigger company than 5 years ago when I joined, each team is pretty lean and you can take on as much responsibility as you can handle.
review_disliked_text: Unsurprisingly, the hours longer than a standard 9-5 job. While I am at the point where I can control my work week a lot more, I still find myself working much longer hours than should be expected some times due to different teams getting busy at the same time.

review_text: Get some fresh management in there.  Try to break up the elitist club of the folks who have been at MC for a long time.  Get rid of Lotus Notes for goodness sake, and replace it with Microsoft Outlook.
review_liked_text: There is MCU, MasterCard University, where you can learn about processing and the payments industry.  There are some competent and committed people with whom to work.  The facilities are OK, with the big gym and decent dining hall.
review_disliked_text:
The benefits are not that great, especially the medican and dental.  _x000D_
There is a group of folks at MasterCard who have been there for 10 years or more.  That is an elitist club.  They do very little work and put the onus of all the real work onto the new employees.  These employees don't get the pension (like the ol' timers still get), don't get the recognition, and get very little thanks and praise.  In the IPS group, especially, much of the real work is done by outsourcing it to onshore and offshore contractors.

review_liked_text:
As someone who joined APT right out of right out college, after considering other consulting careers, I like APT because I truly believe in the data-driven decision making we enable our clients to do._x000D_
_x000D_
The culture is really great. It's a young, casual, and very friendly environment. Beyond that, I've found that my coworkers are truly invested in my professional development, and are always willing to offer advice on ways I can grow. You're given a lot of independence and responsibility, which can be a little intimidating at first, but is also an exciting challenge._x000D_
_x000D_
Within your first few months, you're able to take on a variety of different rolls on each projects, and gain exposure to many different industries. As the company expands, there are projects in many new industries, from the public sector to pharma.
review_disliked_text: The work life balance could be better. The workload will vary throughout the year, but there are several times throughout the year when there is a lot to be done across many of your projects.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1013911, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for writing this review! We are happy to hear you enjoy working at a company that emphasizes working hard while also having fun. One of the great things about APT is the ability for our employees to get exposure to senior management, so we\u2019re glad you agree!", "response_date_time": "2016-08-31T07:55:23.75", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Keep listening to your employees, iterating based on feedback, and 'testing.' APT is a special place to work, driving substantial value to its clients around the world, and is an exciting place to work.
review_liked_text:
This is an A+ company to work for. APT provides products and services that are extremely valuable to its clients and is a company that fosters innovation, creative thinking and hard work. All of the peers that you will work with here are some of the smartest, hard working and genuinely kind people you will ever meet, and makes working here such a treat. A few other key highlights:_x000D_
_x000D_
- The benefits are excellent (great 401k match, highly competitive salaries, generous PTO/Sick, catered food, great insurance, etc.). _x000D_
unities within the company_x000D_
_x000D_
- Tremendous upward mobility opportunities_x000D_
_x000D_
- Brand new DC office, right next to ballston metro_x000D_
_x000D_
- Amazing leadership who are approachable, thoughtful and genuine in their approach to their employees_x000D_
_x000D_
- Open to new ideas internally around process, from anyone on the team. This is not a top-down culture where everything is driven by leadership, anyone across the team has input into strategy and execution.
review_disliked_text: Be prepared to work hard for long hours.

review_text: Graduate school sponsorship would be a plus
review_liked_text:
-The junior staff is all pretty fun to be with and laid back_x000D_
_x000D_
-Office events (free food, outings, teams, etc)
review_disliked_text:
-The role isn't intellectually stimulating at all - in no way does this compare to MBB consulting like they try to pretend it does. For example, most of the day is spent interacting with the junior analysts of the client, not c-level execs of SVPs. These clients have tests they want to run in mind, so you literally handhold them as they click through buttons to run the test, reset their passwords, etc. There isn't any strategy involved and really no thinking involved. _x000D_
_x000D_
-Poor management- what happens when you don't have people go to b-school and have them go straight through, you have 23/24 year old managers who frankly aren't good managers._x000D_
_x000D_
-No transferable skills - lack of Excel work, some SQL, but you spend most of the time on the APT software which you'll never really use if you try and switch jobs_x000D_
_x000D_
-Lots of very late nights due to multiple cases at a time. When two run hot, it's a problem._x000D_
_x000D_
-For a organization that goes out of the way to say how "flat" it is, there are a lot of politics
employer_responses:
[{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1564667, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for your feedback. I am sorry to hear that you are not happy at APT. First and foremost, we would encourage you to provide this feedback beyond Glassdoor, and to share it directly to your advisor and to the firm. Employee feedback is crucial for ensuring the success of individuals and of the firm. On a personal level, your advisor can work with you on staffing that could be better geared to your preferences and learning opportunities. Through bi-annual firm feedback or our ongoing feedback mechanisms, we welcome your suggestions to improve your experience and to make APT a better place to work.

The Business Consultant role that is central to driving ongoing client value. As the frontline of our client relationships, the role does entail user support and password resets. It also includes client thought partnership, cutting edge analysis, and client presentations at various points of project delivery and levels of experience. 

Realizing that experience is unique across Business Consultants and across teams, if anyone is not receiving the experience they desire, we encourage them to speak to their advisor or HR. Advisors can help identify staffing opportunities that would promote more learning on desired skills. Through projects and training, Business Consultants learn project management, analysis structuring, Excel, or SQL, among other skills. These can be leveraged within APT, and also in business school or in other organizations by our alumni. Outside of the day-to-day, each employee has access to an education budget should they seek additional training while at APT.

When it comes to management, APT promotes a culture of internal growth, and as such many of our Engagement Managers are former Business Consultants. While growth opportunities within APT mean that our Engagement Managers have direct experience with ongoing delivery, we understand the importance of strong management and mentorship, and acknowledge that our manager training is never complete. We recently launched a training program for both experienced Business Consultants and newly promoted Engagement Managers, helping with the transition from individual contributor to manager. We also hold offsites for each role, with training sessions focused on management topics such as enabling leadership or project management. 

Again, we appreciate hearing this and all feedback, and encourage you to share specifics through your advisor or our feedback mechanisms.", "response_date_time": "2018-02-14T07:23:31.537", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Take the time to get to know your people.  Keeping the same direct reports who are loyal to you is not a bad thing, however it is vital to listen closely to others, especially those that bring fresh perspectives and the energy and enthusiasm to make things better.
review_liked_text: Mastercard is an excellent place to work. Very innovative and compensation is outstanding.
review_disliked_text: The executive leader in the BizOps area is super sharp, however there is a HUGE flaw. This leader likes to surround herself with 'yes' people and does not like to be challenged. Her direct reports often are afraid to push back and as a result, the teams working hard each and every day suffer from a lack of support. This is not targeted at every leader in this space, just the EVP and a couple of her directs in particular. There is an old school culture in this area and it requires some house cleaning at the top.

review_text: Stop pretending to be a tech company and change the mindset so that innovation can happen or you’ll become an obsolete company real soon.
review_liked_text:
Mastercard is a great company for women since they are the only place I’ve seen full commitment to 50/50 hiring and even promotion cycles follow this religiously._x000D_
_x000D_
If you’re not a woman company is still fine and you can expect a promotion every 2-4 years but you won’t get access to scholarships or special projects but it’s what it is.
review_disliked_text:
Some areas are definitely overlooked like market delivery. Account managers and advisors get much more benefits and perks it even seems like they are part of a different company._x000D_
_x000D_
Lastly, and I can’t stress this enough MasterCard is NOT a technology company even if they market themselves as such. There is no chance to develop improvements let alone change old process that after a while it gets really painful dealing with all their legacy systems innovation is dead basically and if they want new tech they buy new companies literally.

review_text:
-Be cognizant of your teammates and don't treat them as only a 'human resources'_x000D_
-Really help employees grow in their career, so don't hold them back_x000D_
-When employees are overbooked with tasks and can't always meet the outpacing demands, don't say 'it's a time management issue'_x000D_
-Give hard working internal employees opportunities to grow and not just fill positions with external people.
review_liked_text:
-CEO brings in a new and energizing perspective_x000D_
-CEO also pushes for diversity, change, and innovation_x000D_
-Company is going through a culture change inviting new ideas, perspectives, innovations, millennial employees_x000D_
-Educational assistance for undergrad and grad school is great_x000D_
-Stock prices continue to prosper in reflection of the embraced changes (cultural, technological, innovations)
review_disliked_text:
-Many old school employees (those before IPO) are resistant to change_x000D_
-Many prefer the status quo_x000D_
-Bureaucracy is a problem causing delays in time to market initiatives and embracing new process improvement ideas_x000D_
-Politics at times play major deterrents impacting project and human resource advancements_x000D_
-Employees feel overbooked with tasks and this is considered 'the MasterCard way' . This causes burnouts and employees seek other positions

review_text: Keep up the good work, and the emphasis on our young vibrant culture. We really appreciate your investments in retention and in making sure we're having fun.
review_liked_text: The people are all young and enthusiastic. You get a lot of responsibility quickly, and will work on very interesting problems. This is a great place to get started at a software company, with lots of exposure to senior management (regular meetings with the CTO), and lots of user exposure. Products that you work on will be used extensively and will make a difference in our clients' daily work and business decisions.
review_disliked_text: Sometimes there's so many options for things to work on that I wish I could work on them all---you'll have to share your interesting problems with your co-workers (though you can always help, and hear about what they're up to!).

review_text:
- Don't just look at VP and above for guidance and ideas, consider the "doers" as well. _x000D_
- Take a look at teams and overlap and PLAN before reorgs so the actual people in the roles understand their responsibilities. _x000D_
- don't be afraid to cut the fat_x000D_
- let us finish projects!
review_liked_text:
- Compensation and Benefits overall - Paid volunteer days,  charitable donation matching, great base pay and attainable bonuses._x000D_
- Flexible work - I can work from anywhere_x000D_
- tremendous room to move around the company and grow and try new things_x000D_
- typically great camaraderie amongst people.
review_disliked_text:
- Organizational structure and frequent changes (I had 5 bosses in 2.5 years between attrition and reorg)_x000D_
- Reorgs happen seemingly without  thinking through the new role structures or responsibilities_x000D_
- Highly matrixed - often seems like there are people in 4 diff departments doing the same job_x000D_
- Some people have become lazy/complacent and leave a great divide in work productivity_x000D_
- often large scale initiatives will get halfway (or more) through and then get scrapped.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1546319, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for taking the time to write a review.  We value our employees feedback  and your thoughtful input is appreciated.", "response_date_time": "2018-01-31T13:27:35.187", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: In Digital, Mastercard often treats  engineers as fungible resources, an idea that has been debunked since 1975. I would highly recommend that y'all read The Mythical Man Month by Fred Brooks. The combinatorial explosion (google it) of training / communication overhead is a fantastic example of how Mastercard engineering goes wrong.
review_liked_text:
Mastercard encourages generalized skills and a flexible career path. It's easy to move horizontally within Mastercard to find the right fit. I cycled between product and engineer multiple times while staying with the same product that I had expertise in._x000D_
_x000D_
Mastercard has an affirming employee culture. Among the rank and file there are few abrasive personalities and everyone is generally supportive of each other.
review_disliked_text: Mastercard Digital tends to assign so many people to overlapping roles that responsibility and accountability is completely removed for all but the most senior management.  The way that both product and technology are structured, few groups are empowered to own and execute the success of the product end to end.

review_text: Keep maintaining a positive environment, continue seeking the right talent and promote internal growth.  And continue expanding internal product resources and information.
review_liked_text: Overall, the culture is very positive and inclusive with a lot of diversity throughout the company, which has been a breath of fresh air and speaks to the level of talent.  Most people across the organization are willing to share their knowledge and help wherever they can.  And there are so many incredibly talented people in every team - kudos to the hiring practices.  Additionally, while I haven't been with the organization for long, it seems like there is a lot of opportunity for growth and longevity.  Many people have been with the organization for several years, and have moved throughout different teams.  Last but not least, the overall compensation is very competitive with generous vacation, sick days, and even allocated volunteer days.
review_disliked_text: Sometimes it's unclear who is in charge of what products or services, and you have to ask around a lot to find the right resources.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1926662, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thanks for your thoughtful review! We are a fast growing company,  and I know it can be a challenge to keep abreast of our growing teams. We are revamping our intranet and will offer resources for our employees to connect, and as always you can look up business units and org structures through Workday.", "response_date_time": "2019-01-03T07:30:04.73", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: You need real accountability!  You make it far too easy to hide and gloss over when bad decisions have been made.  Off shore cheap labor can't fix your lack of operational efficiency and lack of commitment to actually taking the right steps to be operationally efficient.
review_liked_text: Great Salary and Benefits, Lots of great technology to works on.  Money to spend on technology often not a blocker. Some of the hardest working and smartest people in IT to work with.
review_disliked_text: Lack of real leadership.  A lot of managers not many leaders.  A lot of politics and not a lot of accountability.  MasterCard is an IT Company but many of the Managers lack any experience, vision, concepts or understanding of managing technology.  MasterCard management tends to jump on the band wagon on technology and rarely seems to lead.    The management has a way of making the engineers and employees feel like they are just cannon fodder.

review_text: Continue to care about our people and our culture, especially as we grow domestically and internationally.  Thank you for all that you do to make APT a great place to work
review_liked_text: APT is a great place to start and grow a career.  I joined as a Business Consultant and continue to be challenged with new responsibilities and leadership opportunities.  The employees and leaders really care about the growth and development of each of us and maintaining a culture and environment that is supportive, engaging, and challenging.  I love working with a top-notch set of individuals who care about producing quality work, the impact we make with our clients, and one another.
review_disliked_text: The consulting track is not a 40 hour a week, never take work home with you job.  Along with responsibility and opportunity comes hard work and some travel, the latter of which increases as you take on more clients.  It's not something I'd give up for the opportunity I have, but it's not for everyone.

review_text: Review the performance metrics and how you compensate employees.
review_liked_text: Mastercard does provide good perks and salaries are competitive. Overall the work-life balance is good and since it's a global company there are some opportunities to move around (though is has decreased in recent years)
review_disliked_text: It is very hard to grow within the company - extremely political and bias. Additionally, because it's a large company you have a lot of people that are just sitting on their job, not looking to grow and not contributing much leaving a lot of work to thus who are looking to grow. The year-end is fake as everyone gets the same and in some cases, you actually see the people who contribute less get further because they spend their time networking instead of doing their job.

review_text: Keep the great culture and continue hiring top talents. Invest more in R&D to maintain APT's competitive advantage in analytics a few years down the road when competitors show up.
review_liked_text:
I started my career at APT and it has been an amazing experience since day one. What I like:_x000D_
- Solving interesting business problems using a powerful software platform, and informing strategic decisions for multibillion dollar companies_x000D_
- Coworkers are really friendly, smart and motivated professionals who push you to do your best_x000D_
- Culture: the work place is fun, and coworkers have great sense of humor_x000D_
- Quick career growth: you have the opportunity to take on a lot of responsibility and make an impact to the firm_x000D_
- Competitive compensation and benefits_x000D_
- The senior leadership team are some of the smartest and kindest persons I have met
review_disliked_text: The new healthcare benefit from Mastercard isn't as great, but this is compensated by other benefits such as 401K matching, a great parental leave policy, childcare benefits

review_text: Tear down Ops & rebuild that team (or at least the process for acquiring hardware) from the ground up... They are a massive roadblock to progress.  In St. Louis, take a page from the Manhattan Tech Hub book and offer a better office location in the Cortex area or at least closer to the city of St. Louis (in addition to the data center in O'Fallon) - you'll attract better new technology talent that way. I love Mastercard but am constantly looking for other opportunities closer to home, where things are happening in tech.
review_liked_text:
Stellar work-life balance with the option for a "flex-work" schedule to support partial working from home_x000D_
Amazing 401k match_x000D_
Stock bonuses granted across all employees in particularly prosperous years_x000D_
Generous vacation policy_x000D_
Inspiring CEO_x000D_
Has largely embraced Agile at the organizational level (SAFE), although there are still plenty of bumps in the road
review_disliked_text:
Still many silos across the organization_x000D_
Core processing development still waterfall_x000D_
For a technology company, the process for scaling hardware is agony._x000D_
The location in O'Fallon is way out in the sticks

review_text: Re-think who you choose to hire & keep as senior leaders.  Listen to employee morale.  Act immediately on feedback about bad  managers (VPs/SVPs/EVPs)  - replace these rather than  the direct reports who do all the hard & effectuve work everyday.
review_liked_text: High pay. Offers stock awards.
review_disliked_text:
Senior leaders protect themselves and are not respectful of staff. A lot of new senior leaders being recruited from non-financial industries (e.g. CPG, Health, Pharma, etc) have no clue of the payments industry business and  really have nothing to contribute other than talk about what they used to do in their old world. _x000D_
_x000D_
Some senior leaders very unprofessional in demeanor  in dealing with staff, peers,  other BU staff during meetings and everyday collaborations.  Obvious favoritism at an all-time high in the organization.  HR useless — pro management and cannot be trusted to support employees.

review_text: Listen to lower level employees more (not just the organization management) and try to meet the industry standards for the pay. MasterCard used to be innovative or at least tried to be once, but now they just try to jump on the wagon after someone else creates a product or follows what other companies do.
review_liked_text: Good work from home options and teamwork. People are helpful and believe in the mission.
review_disliked_text: Career progression is really slow if you are a software engineer in the tech hub. One of the main reasons new hires leave is also because of this. Pay is also low when compared to the market standards of other fintech companies. The management progresses every year but the engineers and architects are stay put. It kind of became a bit toxic to work at since the past one year. My advice for an engineer would be to not make this company your first option.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1941517, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for providing feedback. At Mastercard we focus on enabling our employees to achieve their maximum potential. We empower all of our employees to seek development opportunities and progressions with a minimum of 12 months in a role to be considered for a new role. Our compensation philosophy not only includes a competitive pay structure, but annual bonuses, flexible work schedule and a generous benefits program.", "response_date_time": "2019-01-16T11:20:16.933", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text:
Look in the mirror and reflect:_x000D_
1.  Am I the person I aspired to be as a child?  _x000D_
2.  What are my motivators and why do I work at MasterCard?_x000D_
3.  Whom do I serve - the betterment of the corporation and my team, or myself?
review_liked_text: Technology.  Challenge.  Better than average salary structures.  Other Fortune 100 companies look to benefit from the experiences a lengthy tenure at MasterCard brings.
review_disliked_text:
The culture changed significantly after becoming a publically traded company.  MasterCard now resembles any other corporate entity; it's lost its sense of fellowship, teamwork and identity.  It's been a stressful, but rewarding culture in the past; however, more recently it's become especially cut-throat and overly competitive. _x000D_
_x000D_
Office dwelling management, VPs (Sr. Business Leaders) and above, are very difficult to trust - they value their bonus structure more than their employees or commitments.  _x000D_
_x000D_
Be careful, not all departments are created alike.  Some are pure meat grinders with little or no work/life balance.

review_text: Start listening to your engineers as to how things should be done. Product decisions is holding the company back from archiving its goals.   Also trust your engineers to do the work and stop trying to micro manage everything, it didn't use to be this way until recent management change.
review_liked_text: Room to learn new things and use cutting edge technology.
review_disliked_text:
Management are micro managers that are constantly wanting a status update but won't give the team room to do their work.

There is no work life balance.  They expect you to show up early, leave late, work through lunch and weekends.  The place is been filled with contractors and a lot of H1 workers so the employee feels the pressure to have the same work schedule as said contractors.

review_text: Clean out the parochial, old boy middle management and hire new blood from outside the company to change the Tayloristic, cynical view of employee management as a mere economic transaction.
review_liked_text: Good benefits, nice campus. Some truly talented, albeit frustrated employees.
review_disliked_text:
Cut throat environment rife with nepotism.  Unprofessional, bullying and dishonest behavior tolerated among middle management. Little collaboration or teamwork due to a bonus payout structure that rewards individuals for seeking personal “wins” at the expense of the team. Dictatorial management that preaches agile and empowerment but practices strict control and punishes initiative or honest feedback. Managers are not held to any performance standard or benchmarks common to the industry, and treat employees like pieces on a chess board.
Very misleading recruiting practices. 
Dishonesty, harassment, bullying and disrespect are tolerated and excused among department management team. 
Many peers talk about “Golden handcuffs,” “keeping their heads down,” “avoiding getting their hands slapped,” etc.

review_text: Make junior team members feel heard, and build a more robust feedback culture - including opportunities for upward feedback that will actually be acted upon
review_liked_text: Flexible working hours and generous vacation policy. Kind and motivated coworkers, with a culture that is more collegiate than competitive. In many cases, you will feel empowered to identify and tackle problems outside your regular job responsibility - a great opportunity to tackle new challenges and learn. (In other cases, attempting to do so may bring about criticism, which will be confusing/ frustrating.)
review_disliked_text: As part of a large company, be expected to ask to fit into boxes. Sometimes there is lack of recognition of individual needs and you may feel disempowered.  Limited feedback culture - you're encouraged to share feedback on peers and junior members, not so much with leadership or company-wide processes. Slow-moving . Tech jobs not compensated at the industry standard
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 2558669, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thanks for taking the time to write a review.  I\u2019m happy to hear that you enjoy our flexible work environment and feel empowered to grow and learn. As an employee, you have several options to provide feedback. Our employee experience survey is an excellent opportunity to share feedback with leadership across the organization. Additionally, we encourage you to share feedback with your manager or HRBP. Mastercard\u2019s compensation programs include a robust benefits package and a generous 401K match. We also conduct an annual compensation analysis to ensure that we stay competitive in the market.", "response_date_time": "2020-03-11T13:41:19.86", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Find a plan and stick to it.
review_liked_text: One of the reasons I enjoyed working for MasterCard was the camaraderie between my colleagues and the way the departments were able to interact with each other.  I also felt comfortable with knowing that if I needed to talk to Management about something, that the door was always open.  I liked that they had plenty of resources available to increase your knowledge base, and they encouraged self improvement as well as career development.  Management was quite flexible with time off and I saw in most cases they were willing to work with you if you needed something, be it advice, assistance, whatever.
review_disliked_text: The only real downside about working at MasterCard was that there seemed to be frequent reorganizations.  It makes for tense management, in my opinion.  Some other downsides were the political aspect of working in certain departments, but you will find that in any office.  As with any and everything else, it all starts with the people.

review_text: Indian mentality is killing the US work ethic. US employees are working ungodly hours due to lack of support, experience, and can-do attitude from the Pune office. Women ARE smart and just as important. Keep that in mind next time you denigrate your female counterparts.
review_liked_text:
Good Pay_x000D_
Good 401k match_x000D_
Good Bonus
review_disliked_text:
Many US jobs lost due to India office opening, however lack of interest and accountability from India office is holding back progress in many areas._x000D_
Upper management does not have your back. Watch out - very high school, playing favorites._x000D_
Too many hours expected (70+) but labeled as "work/life balance" when many hours are being worked in the evenings and weekends._x000D_
Stress level is very high due to lack of management support and understanding of daily operations. They should listen to their Leaders, coach when necessary but at least make an attempt to show you back up your team, yes even in the tough times._x000D_
Management will keep you from moving to another area (even if lateral), very controlling._x000D_
HR will not help you, so don't go there. Fly under the radar. It's the only way to survive until you can find your next opportunity elsewhere.

review_text: Find ways to automate, speed up, or outsource some of the basic software support mentioned above so that consultants can focus on strategic work.
review_liked_text:
1. The people are incredibly smart and enjoyable to work with_x000D_
_x000D_
2. There is a lot less politicking around staffing than at many other consulting firms which means that you will not get pigeonholed into a specific role or into working with only a small group of people._x000D_
_x000D_
3. The pay is significantly higher than every other consulting firm I've heard about and people are quickly promoted. There is no ceiling after 2-3 years where you are basically forced to go back to grad school._x000D_
_x000D_
4. You get to engage with your clients rather than doing a lot of grunt work and then just sitting in meetings and taking notes - this is unusual.
review_disliked_text:
It would be really nice if they sponsored business or other graduate school._x000D_
_x000D_
A small portion of the business consultant role is really basic software support (i.e. advising people where to click, reset passwords, etc.).

review_text: Make junior team members feel heard, and build a more robust feedback culture - including opportunities for upward feedback that will actually be acted upon
review_liked_text: Flexible working hours and generous vacation policy. Kind and motivated coworkers, with a culture that is more collegiate than competitive. In many cases, you will feel empowered to identify and tackle problems outside your regular job responsibility - a great opportunity to tackle new challenges and learn. (In other cases, attempting to do so may bring about criticism, which will be confusing/ frustrating.)
review_disliked_text: As part of a large company, be expected to ask to fit into boxes. Sometimes there is lack of recognition of individual needs and you may feel disempowered.  Limited feedback culture - you're encouraged to share feedback on peers and junior members, not so much with leadership or company-wide processes. Slow-moving . Tech jobs not compensated at the industry standard
