review_text: Continue pushing for all Managers of people to realize that managing others is a distinction and honor (as I heard our CEO saying once...) that shouldn't be taken lightly.  Supporting, coaching, respecting, guiding, teaching and ensuring the best environment to excel professionally and personally should be a given, not a rare thing that some of us are lucky to find.
review_liked_text: I reflect back on what an amazing journey it has been. Never regretted even for a second having agreed to work here.  Great company for work for, where you have all the resources and support to tailor your own career.  It's definitely been a fun ride !!
review_disliked_text: I think pointing at "cons" can be personal. What's a bad thing for somebody, may not be a bad thing for me. Difficult to say, I've always focused on all the positive things around here.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1789139, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thanks  for taking the time to write a review. Happy Anniversary!  I'm glad to hear that you have enjoyed your career journey at Mastercard.", "response_date_time": "2018-08-28T11:06:47.28", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text:
Young talent is leaving the company for higher salaries at other tech companies. _x000D_
_x000D_
I think it is important to give the young talent a strong reason to stay. They will become so much more valuable to the company once they have the initial 3-5 years of experience, yet this is around the time where I see most of the young talent moving elsewhere._x000D_
_x000D_
The 401k matching is great, but if someone is getting an offer making 15k+ more a year elsewhere, you probably are not going to keep them. Or you may retain the employee for 4 years, and then lose them.
review_liked_text:
Great 401k Match_x000D_
Decent Annual Bonus_x000D_
Potential Stock Options
review_disliked_text:
Be prepared to present a strong case. _x000D_
_x000D_
You are cutting yourself short if you do not ever push for a higher salary. _x000D_
_x000D_
It will incrementally increase year to year regardless, but presenting a solid case/reason will help you significantly._x000D_
_x000D_
Location contributes to your base salary significantly (up to 25% higher in NYC vs. places like St. Louis, Austin, Miami, etc.

review_text: Hard to argue or advise management when the stock price is performing as well as it is.
review_liked_text: Fabulous business model where revenue grows double digits no matter what anyone does.  At least paying lip service to "Doing Well By Doing Good" with all the social responsibility efforts...perhaps this is all we can expect from a for-profit company.  Benefits are still good, but have declined over the years.  Work-from-home flexibility exists for individual contributors.
review_disliked_text: Need more single-minded focus on core efforts.  Right now there is an "innovation" mantra that results in thousands of small projects taking up a lot of time.  Not really a lot of data-driven decision-making either but that may be because "innovation" involves taking risks that may be years ahead of their time.  Also lots of encouragement to move from one role to another every couple years, which creates continuity problems and accountability problems in an industry where change takes a lot of time.

review_text: Don't overlook the remote worker when looking to add a new team member or promote someone. Typically we're always available, work way more than 40-50 hours and have an amazing response time since you always know where you can find them.
review_liked_text: I have worked for MasterCard for more than 13 years. During my tenure, 10 of the last 13 I have been working in a remote US location. During that time I have been promoted 3x and can't express enough the real work/life balance my working situation has afforded me.  While maybe not for everyone and not available for every position, this working situation provides everything I need. I have no interest in moving and changing. The company out pays other companies I have friends at - all of whom want to come to MasterCard.
review_disliked_text: Nothing out of the ordinary when you work for a large, global organization. There is always a struggle between priorities, lines of business silos and business vs. technology.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1612145, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for your review and for choosing a priceless career at Mastercard!", "response_date_time": "2018-03-26T07:46:23.66", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Build a strong and central company culture as managers currently walk all over the current weak company culture.
review_liked_text:
- generous bonus and stock options  (for senior managers)_x000D_
- a global and stable technology network_x000D_
- interacting with colleagues from all over the world; very few companies are global in the way Mastercard is global
review_disliked_text:
- there are as many cultures as there are managers; the company culture is weak or non-existent_x000D_
- virtually all the acquisitions made in the past 7 years have flopped_x000D_
- senior leadership does not hold itself accountable (e.g. for failed acquisitions)_x000D_
- pays a lot of lip-service to (management cannot stop talking about) doing good but has invested very little in that area in reality_x000D_
- to get promoted and do well in the company, you need to schmooze, be from a certain South Asian country and/or have godfathers. It operates like a country club.

review_text:
- Don't continue to fund poor performing projects. 
- Do more to recognize and reward mid- to low-level employees.  There is a lot of effort put into "elevating the elevated" (recognizing the executive team or their directs)
review_liked_text:
- Good benefits, great 401k
- Good leadership and vision
- Management truly wants good things for employees (e.g. announcing no layoffs during the pandemic in 2020 gave everyone the peace of mind about their job despite their situation at home)
- Lots of great people working on interesting things
- Ability to move around is based on your own networking;
review_disliked_text:
- Employees who have been with the company 5+ years are underpaid, and salaries do not keep up with market conditions
- Moving up can be quite difficult, but lateral moves are encouraged to gain broader experience
- Culture varies by group, some managers and group leaders can be back-stabby or have different unspoken policies that don't align to top line leadership

review_text: Clean up the layers and layers of decision makers and key stake holders. Trust a few talented people over many. Build functional product and service pods, for faster strategy and execution. Decrease silos where possible. Don't hire so many highly paid, highly titled employees per unit. If everyone is a VP or higher it makes it hard to delegate and get the core fundamental work done. The down in the trenches work. Let ideation lead and proper strategy and support back up new ideas.
review_liked_text: Great pay and excellent benefits! Lots of opportunities in multiple dynamic fields across diverse range of products, services, etc. Very open and supportive culture. Some internal groups are much better then others, so do your research.
review_disliked_text: Some groups are very isolated, and even though they want to operate like a leading tech company, they often act more like a big bank or finance organization. Lots of layers and tape. Some internal groups have reputations for being more high stress and demanding then others.

review_liked_text:
I have worked at APT for a little over 3 years. Some of my favorite things about working at APT include:_x000D_
_x000D_
- Awesome people: Many people at APT are friends both inside and outside of the office. It's great to be excited to come to work every day and know you will be with great people who are also extremely intelligent._x000D_
- Opportunity to find your niche: While there is always the expectation that you give it your all towards your actual role, APT also offers the opportunity for every employee to find the things that excite them most and get involved there (examples include helping to conduct analytic investigations, being involved in campus recruiting and interviewing, etc.)_x000D_
- Chances for ownership: People with all levels of seniority can own features and projects of varying sizes.
review_disliked_text: While it varies by role, everyone at APT has a lot on their plate. This is great for growing in your career, but can also lead to a struggle in work-life balance.

review_text: I would advise finance management to rethink who they are putting in senior roles ... there are many unqualified managers that are not supportive of their teams.  Poor allocation of responsibilities amongst team members.  No cross training or sharing of ideas within the function.
review_liked_text: Management encourages free exchange of ideas and suggestions for improvement.  Great benefits (although reduced over the last 7 years) and opportunities to grow if you join at a junior level.  Be sure to take classes to learn about the industry and how transaction processing works.
review_disliked_text: MC is a changing environment - it will be much easier to join if you are under 30 and do not mind working hard; not very family friendly.  It is a progressive culture but do not be fooled into thinking the games are there to be used, just looked at.

review_text: Replace Advisors Senior Leadership, who show no ability to push forward change in terms of Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning or Data Science, largely because their understanding of these difficult subjects is little more than being able to recite buzzwords frequently, loudly and embarrassingly.
review_liked_text: Very interesting data, little else
review_disliked_text: Strongly encourage anyone with integrity, talent and ambition NOT to work at Mastercard, especially if you are in mid/career and/or work in technology.  The company is a marketing company that has taken on the veneer of tech company and struggles to keep pace with the state-of-the-state in AI/ML/Data Science. The data can be fascinating, but Advisors is little more than a back office and reporting shop and its choke hold on analytics functions prevents other teams from building competencies in Data Science.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1732987, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for your review.  We\u2019d like an opportunity to respond as employee satisfaction is critical to our success. As you know, technology is the core of our business. We have very strong resources in the AI/ML/Data Science arena as we recently acquired an award winning Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning company that does just that.  We are confident in the abilities of those in our new team and feel they add strong value to Mastercard\u2019s robust existing suite of AI-based products and offerings.", "response_date_time": "2018-07-12T07:05:28.12", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text:
- Mastercard needs to cut dead weight and C level needs to really start examining who is being promoted and why_x000D_
- Make HR great again!... HR function is quite poor and really doesn't involve itself in the organization of talent below the group head / SVP level
review_liked_text:
Mastercard has some really smart folks and has a fairly clear focus on its migration toward being a technology company._x000D_
Pay is fairly commensurate with other companies in the industry. _x000D_
Good benefits
review_disliked_text:
- Incredibly political,  especially as you try and advance your career beyond "director" level_x000D_
- While there are some really intelligent folks at Mastercard, the leadership below the c-suite level leaves something to be desired

review_text: Reading other reviews, other ex-colleagues simply say "change management". In my experience, the team that I worked with in Loyalty Solutions have all resigned or requested internal transfers due to the overall negligent structure in Loyalty Solutions. When I was at MasterCard, and with the high attrition rate on my team, HR was practically inexistent. Overall - great company, but the Loyalty Solutions and Merchant team NEEDS A LOT OF HELP! With the current leadership structure, it's sad to see that amazing products go to waste. Would be great if Ron Garrow could spend some of his time with this team vs the core teams.
review_liked_text: Global company, good benefits, and if you select the right division within MasterCard you'll find strategic growth opportunities. Unfortunately, I cannot write more than 20 words expressing "pros".
review_disliked_text: I worked under Loyalty Solutions, Merchant Value Proposition team based in San Carlos. The lack of leadership, strategy, and management is why I decided to leave MasterCard, and why the attrition rate is at an all time high within that division. Management went through a huge re-org, implementing a new management team that is mediocre at best.

review_text: Continue to get feedback from employees so that you can keep track of how the company is evolving as it grows. Put in place systems that allow for the company to keep its fun, collaborative, and innovative culture even as the company grows.
review_liked_text:
- Fun and collaborative culture_x000D_
- Strong focus on career development and progression_x000D_
- Have opportunities to work on projects that interest you_x000D_
- Get to share your work with Senior VPs and the CTO_x000D_
- Everyone's opinions are heard and appreciated, no matter how long they've been with the company_x000D_
- Have a strong focus on innovation within the company_x000D_
- Collects employee feedback often to make improvements to the company_x000D_
- A lot of great perks (vacation, free food, game room, etc.)
review_disliked_text: The company is starting to grow rapidly, which means there will be challenges with keeping the company culture intact, although I think the company is aware of this and is taking the right steps towards ensuring this isn't an issue.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1096103, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for providing this feedback! It\u2019s great to hear that after being here for less than a year you have been working on projects that interest you and are experiencing development in your career. As you\u2019ve noted, everyone\u2019s opinions are heard and we appreciate all of the feedback we receive from our employees. As we grow, we will certainly make it a priority to keep gathering employee feedback in order to maintain and improve our strong company culture.", "response_date_time": "2016-11-30T16:36:18.497", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Be transparent and honest as you cut office culture and perks
review_liked_text: There's a great 401k policy - but upper management loves to ignore other problems by constantly pushing how great the 401k policy is.
review_disliked_text: APT, a company Mastercard acquired, was a great place to work but Mastercard has killed the company culture that APT used to have. Despite claiming to be a technology company, Mastercard has slashed salaries for new technology campus hires by 15%, cut the many office perks we used to have, and instituted tons of bureaucracy for nearly every basic process. Software engineers are not valued and the organization as a whole has a culture of outsourcing development, even for business critical projects. Many of the top engineers have already left for greener pastures. I would not recommend Mastercard Data & Services as a good place to work for new campus hires.

review_text: Diversity is a big issue especially in your management committee.    Create a culture of collaboration with the right tools which can help with the hierarchical and office politics.  Give directs ability to give performance reviews of their managers.
review_liked_text: Cool products, good growth, great benefits, and brand recognition, able to move to new roles every year
review_disliked_text: Hierarchical (i.e. gate keeping, territory guarding), feedback not collaboration culture, old-school WFH infrastructure (i.e. Skype no video, stripped down Teams), path to promotion is unclear (there are people with a lot of experience with low titles), mostly South Asian and white leadership/workforce (they are all that are featured in internal comms). Product dev mostly starts in the US and then adapted to the regions (common but problematic given it's mostly white people speculating on regional needs and making them sell these products)

review_text: Hard working conscientious workers are hard to come by.  Please do not use up your good workers by having them work day in and day out.  More resources are needed to assist with the workload.
review_liked_text: There are many opportunities for personal and career development, for example, there are free online courses in banking, emotional intelligence, leadership skills, etc.  The health center has a variety of activities for club members as well as non-club members.  The cafe has a wide variety of healty options.  Telecommuting has really taken hold this year, so there's more opportunities to balance work and family life.  The ability to move up is available if you have good management.  Industry information is paid for by the company, so there is no reason for not being in the know.
review_disliked_text: Too much work and not enough people to do it, which translates into early burnout.

review_text: Create innovative products that can actually be used and earn profits.  Do better market research.  Mobile MoneySend, PayPass, InControl and others "sound good" but are not serving the needs of those who would use and pay for them as services.
review_liked_text: Very well positioned company to take advantage of existing as well as future trends in payment industry.  Multiple connections and alliances among banks, processors and corporate partners enable MasterCard to be viewed as an attractive partner for electronic commerce and payments. Potential is high, execution is a challenge.
review_disliked_text: Very slow to enable advancements to take advantage of market conditions in a timely manner.  Many self-driven innovations fall short of market needs.  Current management changes and personnel displacements have created large gaps in expertise and "brain drain" syndrome.  They appear destined to repeat past failures due to lack of experience among market-facing staff.  Potential is offset by inability to execute.

review_text: HR should listen to their employees, not simply nod and say "I understand."  That does not produce results.  When People Effectiveness Survey results are published to management and HR 1. Commend those with high results and 2. Deal withi those who have low results.  Don't ignore them.
review_liked_text: Excellent pay, benefits, vacation, 401k, holidays.  If working for the right manager, life is very good.  Much room for advancement, coaching and education are encouraged.
review_disliked_text: Some high-level management have no business "managing" people.  Complaints are put back on the lower-level management, who end up stuck in the middle with no alternative but to move to another position.  If you are friends with one of these high-level managers, you're in - if not, better looki for another position.  On the other side of the house, there aren't many promotions in current positions (even as you grow) unless you apply to a higher level.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 549366, "language_id": null, "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for your candid remarks.  We take reviews and our employee surveys seriously to garner insight for continuous improvement!", "response_date_time": "2014-09-08T07:21:36.253", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Keep on doing what you're doing, it seems to be working!
review_liked_text: MasterCard was a great place to intern. We had a small intern group spread across many different areas of the company, but our departments and HR made sure we felt welcome and integrated into the organization. They have really thought through their internship program and had weekly educational sessions focusing on resume writing, knowledge about the bank, personal strengths, etc. We even visited the floor of the NYSE! The hours were great, the work was not overwhelming and was appropriate for my level of work experience at the time, and my coworkers were infinately helpful. Overall, the atmosphere and people were just perfect for me.
review_disliked_text: It was a sophmore internship, so it is not like other financial internships where you can expect a fulltime offer after the internship. Really, other than that, I can't think of one negative thing.

review_text: Keep it up! As the company expands globally, work to keep a central identity.
review_liked_text: APT is an absolutely first tier consulting and data science organization. Despite now 15 years of experience, they maintain an innovative, open, and entrepreneurial atmosphere.  The management is superb, the problems are the future of consulting, the vibe is friendly and supportive. The opportunities are excellent - APT put me in the board room of a Billion dollar company within 6 months of my joining. The best part, however, is the rigor and empirical approach to consulting which APT takes. The scientific approach to business question is powerful and highly satisfying. APT has carved out a name for itself and will continue to grow well into the future.
review_disliked_text: Rapid growth can make the company unfocused at times. Flat, merit based hierarchy encourages people to work to stand out, when sometimes people need to gel more tightly behind a set of ideas.

review_text: Please LISTEN to what the CEO has to say. If you can't do the job, step down and let someone more capable do it OR if you don't want to, tap into fresh perspective and not your network who've been there 15+ years. Change cannot happen this way. Look forward to seeing MasterCard achieving great things in the future!
review_liked_text:
- Great CEO who pushes people out of their comfort zone and challenges the status quo_x000D_
- Good pay, along with good benefits_x000D_
-  Slowly changing the way the company is operating by becoming more technology driven. Huge plus. _x000D_
- Focus on innovation, youth, and a multigenerational workforce_x000D_
- Culture is significantly improving by being more transparent
review_disliked_text:
- There are too many people there resistant to change_x000D_
- A strong network of people who've been there 15+ years_x000D_
- Takes forever to get something basic done; no one wants to take accountability or ownership of anything

review_text: Dig a bit deeper into what people are telling you. A great strategy can be easily derailed by poor execution.  Value both types of work, strategic and tactical, equally.  Learn to truly prioritize and not just pile projects on top of one another.
review_liked_text: Great benefits. Some very smart people.  Beginning a culture shift over to a technology company. Lot's of upside.
review_disliked_text: There's some deadweight in the organization that could easily be eliminated if the company had the fortitude.  Marketing is a bit of a mess as a function, especially the US region (lot's of firedrills, senior management says "yes" to everything leaving mid and junior level managers to sort things out and work long hours).  Also, if you want to truly be a tech innovator and attract truly innovative people, you might want to consider moving HQ out of the sleepy suburbs and into NYC.

review_text: Poor management, can't decide which management style to adopt so they change every few months.  MC management will not read these reviews because they really don't care!
review_liked_text:
Nice people, solidarity among employees. Young workforce._x000D_
They pay fairly well (but you won't have time to spend it).
review_disliked_text:
People with seniority tend to be let go because they are expensive/expendable.  In the real world, this cost-saving technique is call age discrimination._x000D_
Management is completely clueless about what their direct reports are doing -- reviews are managed like high school popularity contests._x000D_
Everyone under middle management is expected to work "more than 40 hours" per week.  This is glossed over in the interview, but it really means at least 60 hour per week and 24/7 availability._x000D_
Mandatory United Way donations; "strong encouragement" to bank at First National Bank of St. Louis (a silent partner of MC).

review_text: Managers that have the same direct reports for too long can be a signal that their is favoritism.  Change in management is good to keep all teams fresh and can create synergy between teams.
review_liked_text:
MasterCard is a fast paced company that is continually changing which offers staff the opportunity to advance their knowledge from a technology and payments industry perspective._x000D_
_x000D_
Outstanding medical, dental, 401 k, and other benefits. _x000D_
_x000D_
MC  supports the LGBT community and this year became the primary sponsor for the St. Louis Pridefest._x000D_
_x000D_
MC provides daily communication on the happenings of our teams around the globe.  Additionally, MC offers partner benefits and has for many years._x000D_
_x000D_
The management team at MC is responsive to issues that may arise in the work place.
review_disliked_text: MC has it's own culture that is very competitive because we hire the best and brightest.  This can be a difficult adjustment when first entering it's workforce.

review_text: Get rid of the dinosaurs, both in Management and non-management roles, so you can move to the next level. Pay accordingly to keep and attract new talent. You can't compete with Silicon Valley, so don't compare yourself to one.
review_liked_text:
• Growing industry
• Work-life balance (for some departments)
• Opportunities to move across functions within the company
• Cool innovative products and solutions
review_disliked_text:
• A lot of bureaucracy and politics. You have to "rub" shoulders with the right people to get ahead.
• Underpaid across all functions, especially tech... It brands itself as a technology company but doesn't pay like one.
• Risk averse. The company needs to take on more risks if it wants to become the leader in payments.
• Management needs to become more accountable and make more decisions instead of depending on their subordinates.

review_text: Keep up the facade and damage control because the law suits are right behind you.
review_liked_text: Brand name company and well recognized.  Staff are very good.  Salary and benefits good.....however.....
review_disliked_text:
Mastercard must be worried.  This video they made (above) is clearly trying to control the bad press about all their recent firings.  There are many people finally speaking out about their age discrimination firings in the US and abroad.  _x000D_
They are posting bogus jobs at locations (like Belgium) to give the impression that the office is still relevant when everyone internally knows all the jobs are going (or gone) to London and regions and the office is being closed in a few years.  I know for a fact that internal HR people create bogus postings about how great the company is,  on sites like Glassdoor to counteract the negative ones.  HR and reviews are used as managers to get back at employees or get rid of employees.  It is a great set up.

review_text: Get rid of 18+ year management...they are done;  Take a close look at managers supervising employees - they have no processes, no clue, don't care to manage, improve the team or grow the business
review_liked_text: The future, after 5-8 years, then more of the dead wood is gone;  CEO has great promise but style may be stifling open conversation and decisions based on facts
review_disliked_text: Senior managers are waiting for retirement, don't care to advance business or manage their staff, they either try to do as little as possible or spend their time creating crises or complex projects that don't make sense;  HR is useless, keep incompetent managers, ignore talent under their noses, focus too much on outside talent, they just manage benefits

review_text: Continue placing an emphasis on listening to employee feedback and exploring ways to better integrate with Mastercard colleagues.
review_liked_text:
APT is a great place to work. Everyone in product development is not only very smart and knowledgeable, but always open to new ideas and trying to improve how we create software. This inclusive culture of makes it very enjoyable to come into work every day._x000D_
_x000D_
APT also does a great job with career growth. The review cycle is every six months and advisors aggregate information from everyone you work with (from new hires to SVPs) to make sure you know how to grow professionally. They place a heavy emphasis on investing in their employees and it definitely shows.
review_disliked_text: As we further integrate with Mastercard, there are multiple challenges with communicating with colleagues outside of APT.  Trying to do anything with Mastercard coworkers usually takes 3x longer than it should and can be very frustrating.

review_liked_text: Pay is great and the company is located in Westchester which is a great commute for those within 15-20 minutes of the location.  Lot of great people that work at MC.
review_disliked_text: Leadership is based on ensuring you sit well with the CEO.. if not... you're out. Lots of miserable people.  No opportunity for growth especially for minorities... horrible bosses which is encouraged by CEO... Company has invested funds into getting rid of positions or people that don't meet the current "culture".  Employees are encouraged to hire talent that are under 30 to drive culture change driven by the CEO.  However the catch is that the new talent get frustrated as there is no room to grow.  If they feel you get frustrated (young or seasoned talent), they will eliminate your role.  Not very innovative and trying hard to hire talent to make them innovative and eliminate those that have been there for a while.

review_text: If you have to preach values, maybe as leaders truly demonstrate value behavior and lead by example. Say what you mean, but more importantly, MEAN WHAT YOU SAY. Truly make the annual management surveys “anonymous”. Don’t launch a “witch hunt” across your team(s) when you receive less than favorable rating. Give employees time for personal growth. The “do more with less” mentality was fine during Covid, but we’re well past that today.
review_liked_text: Somewhat allows remote working, depending on role and location, but the policy is inconsistently applied across business units. Strong stock price.
review_disliked_text: Leadership stresses a culture of decency. It’s lip service. I’ve seen some of the most disgusting displays of rude behavior, including lying, at the senior management and executive levels. Inconsistent treatment of men and women still prevalent. Little diversity at higher levels of management and responsibility prevails.

review_text: As we grow, we need to celebrate the work that individuals do that impacts the company.
review_liked_text:
Get reviewed every 6-months; promotions vary from every 1.5 (very fast) to 2.5 (standard growth) years; can give feedback for the company as well as receive it._x000D_
_x000D_
Office environment is very welcoming and collaborative. _x000D_
_x000D_
Projects are a combination of self-selected by priority and interest. There are no managers dictating work and deadlines, but a cross-functional team that determines work together._x000D_
_x000D_
Room for creativity in daily work, and during hackathons and Idea Marketplace (up to 1/5 of an engineer's time on non-team-based projects). _x000D_
_x000D_
Focus on warm culture, connecting the engineers to users, and supporting between the departments.
review_disliked_text: Employee training is all internal, and engineers can go to conferences once a year - in general, I think we are missing out on some industry knowledge.

review_text: I worked as contractor and completed tasks on time and team provided positive feedback. We had project planing meeting and created tasks for next 4 months. Progress on tasks were going well and things were on time in some tasks ahead of time.  After working for months smoothly I got call that I was fired without telling me any reason. What I guess is that upper management has no idea  what developers are working on or may be they just hate you as a person, can be any reason.
review_liked_text: in office Cafe food is good
review_disliked_text: People with poor technical background are in upper management tech positions. They can fire you without any reason or just because they don't like you as a person.

review_text: Many employees were on-boarded by a very deceptive manager at MasterCard, and many ex-colleagues don't want to say anything given their work visa, potential retaliation, among other concerns. I would encourage HR to have a bigger presence, and actually talk to employees that under the group head level.
review_liked_text: Great talent in the San Carlos satellite office, especially on the Products & Platforms and Merchant Sales side of the business. MasterCard has great assets, and hopefully they'll bring the right management team to lead these efforts.
review_disliked_text: Excessive red tape. The biggest issue I had during my tenure was trusting management and HR. From my hire date, all the way through my exit from MasterCard, everyone complained about being promised x and getting y & z. Many disgruntled ex-colleagues and a few still remain at MasterCard, as they believe one day this culture will eventually change. The biggest problem with loyalty solutions is that they lack leadership and the key executives have limited or no knowledge leading their respective teams, which explains the revenue issues and huge turnover.

review_liked_text:
Mastercard has a great 401k match and good bonus structure. 

St. Louis and Purchase locations are very accommodating. Very nice cafeterias, open office seating with contemporary styling. Makes coming to work fun. Mastercard also has recreational amenities such as a large fitness center, walking paths, pool tables, foosball, and video arcade games around the campus.

Although Mastercard is pushing for a hybrid work environment, they only ask for two days per week on-site. Most companies ask for three on-site. Those days can also be what works best for you. If you do not live near an office, you can still become employed as a 100% remote associate.

Diversity and Inclusion are important and engrained into Mastercard's culture. In fact, D&I was important at Mastercard, long before most organizations were "getting on board" with it.
review_disliked_text: No cons one year in.

review_text: Review the business leader and above in the GBSC  transaction services and replace with competent leadership.
review_liked_text:
The company pays better than market to their employees.   The time off policy is very generous.   The O_x000D_
Fallon building has many perks for the employee.
review_disliked_text: The culture and the actual environment are totally different.    MasterCard HR tries to promote work/life balance.   Putting the employees first.      The actuality is long hours,  overworked staff,  and a hostile work environment.    Management is worried about covering themselves and showing up others so they look good with no regard to the result of the dept. or other employees trying to do their best.

review_text: Be more involved with your lower levels and listen to changes they suggest.
review_liked_text: Benefits/pay are really good and work/life balance is pretty good as well.  As far as big companies go, it offers all the standard things.
review_disliked_text: They promised a lot when I interviewed in terms of training, projects, international travel, and generally made it sound like an exciting place to be.  That wasn't really the case.  The training was slapped together last minute and I got stuck doing mundane projects for the whole year and a half that I worked there.  Even when I asked for more challenging work, I was mostly ignored.  Beyond that, my boss probably couldn't even tell you where my desk was and I maybe saw him once a month - not ideal in my opinion.

review_text: Many employees were on-boarded by a very deceptive manager at MasterCard, and many ex-colleagues don't want to say anything given their work visa, potential retaliation, among other concerns. I would encourage HR to have a bigger presence, and actually talk to employees that under the group head level.
review_liked_text: Great talent in the San Carlos satellite office, especially on the Products & Platforms and Merchant Sales side of the business. MasterCard has great assets, and hopefully they'll bring the right management team to lead these efforts.
review_disliked_text: Excessive red tape. The biggest issue I had during my tenure was trusting management and HR. From my hire date, all the way through my exit from MasterCard, everyone complained about being promised x and getting y & z. Many disgruntled ex-colleagues and a few still remain at MasterCard, as they believe one day this culture will eventually change. The biggest problem with loyalty solutions is that they lack leadership and the key executives have limited or no knowledge leading their respective teams, which explains the revenue issues and huge turnover.

St. Louis and Purchase locations are very accommodating. Very nice cafeterias, open office seating with contemporary styling. Makes coming to work fun. Mastercard also has recreational amenities such as a large fitness center, walking paths, pool tables, foosball, and video arcade games around the campus.

Although Mastercard is pushing for a hybrid work environment, they only ask for two days per week on-site. Most companies ask for three on-site. Those days can also be what works best for you. If you do not live near an office, you can still become employed as a 100% remote associate.

The company pays better than market to their employees.   The time off policy is very generous.   The O_x000D_
Fallon building has many perks for the employee.

The actuality is long hours,  overworked staff,  and a hostile work environment.    Management is worried about covering themselves and showing up others so they look good with no regard to the result of the dept. or other employees trying to do their best.

review_text: Be more involved with your lower levels and listen to changes they suggest.
review_liked_text: Benefits/pay are really good and work/life balance is pretty good as well.  As far as big companies go, it offers all the standard things.
review_disliked_text: They promised a lot when I interviewed in terms of training, projects, international travel, and generally made it sound like an exciting place to be.  That wasn't really the case.  The training was slapped together last minute and I got stuck doing mundane projects for the whole year and a half that I worked there.  Even when I asked for more challenging work, I was mostly ignored.  Beyond that, my boss probably couldn't even tell you where my desk was and I maybe saw him once a month - not ideal in my opinion.

review_text: Keep bringing in the great strategy and acquisition ideas. While change is good, the employee base should be better explained on the reasons for changes. What is explained when the strategy is set and what happens on the ground seems a bit off.
review_liked_text:
MasterCard is a technology company that is nothing short of a typical bay area company. It is a fast-paced company, there is a strong drive for collaborative  work culture, innovative technology and creativity at every step._x000D_
_x000D_
The bar is set pretty high in comparison to other mid-west companies which makes the workforce somewhat unique in the market that are high-tech._x000D_
_x000D_
MasterCard truly invests in its employees. I was fortunate enough to get so much of training and mentoring.
review_disliked_text: Compared to few years, work-life balance has improved a lot, however I believe there is still a little room for improvement.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1482548, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for taking the time to write a review. We are happy to hear that you are enjoying your priceless career!", "response_date_time": "2017-11-30T09:37:28.62", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Take the time to read and take action on the employee surveys you send out. My colleagues and I took several surveys and conveyed real concerns and constructive feedback, but our feedback was not recognized or acted upon, and leadership only celebrated the positive feedback.
review_liked_text: Interesting work, opportunity to work with people in different industries.
review_disliked_text: Leadership lacks communication, project management, and people management skills. It seems like a lot of people are in leadership positions simply because they outlasted peers who left for other, more organized companies. Lack of opportunity for advancement, and teams are siloed. It is clear that raises and promotions are reserved for those on the tech side of things. Mastercard's "commitment to decency" is simply a marketing ploy without any meaningful internal action. This company seemed to have great potential, but was ultimately incredibly disappointing.

review_text: Create a true developer friendly, engineering and technology focused culture, so that the company and business can still be relevant in the fin-tech era.
review_liked_text: Good pay. Some of work, technologies and technologies are interesting. There are also quite a few managers and engineers that are problem solvers: it was a pleasure to work with those super stars.
review_disliked_text: Long work hours in general (before pandemic). Hectic paces at times. The Scale Agile Framework®, aka SAFe® for software development is a joke for the most part. So was the program increment (PI) meetings. Some departments are quite political in terms of finger pointing when customer impact incident happens. Promotion and lateral move inside are mostly based on age, perception and the relationship with managers (think kiss-up :-), instead of qualification, experience and skills. Diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) is mostly on paper too.

review_text: Stop making your friends into people managers when they lack the ability to managers of technical teams or people managers period. People managers are critical to building the people if they can't it cost the company more money but lost trust and lost team moral.
review_liked_text:
Great Benefits, Occasionally interesting projects if you are in the right team especially if project is a business imperative. _x000D_
Great Top Leadership especially CEO. He is taking this company places. If only an ounce of some of his awesomeness can trickle down to the mid level management.
review_disliked_text:
Too much cronyism. Make that extreme cronyism. It's done so openly it stinks. _x000D_
Forget about work life balance that they preach on paper but do not put in practice.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 535455, "language_id": null, "original_language_id": null, "response": "Your feedback and candor is important to us - thanks for sharing.", "response_date_time": "2014-07-10T09:19:43.867", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Keep up the good job you have been doing so far.
review_liked_text:
Super smart and highly talented pool of people in the company with full of humility. Each and every employee is treated with same level of respect no matter what your role is. The company is very transparent and the level of commitment by the senior employees is unmatchable. Even for the hiring process, the CEO of the company, Anthony Bruce came down to the DC office in the middle of his business trip overseas to meet and introduce every new hire during the orientation and that speaks volumes of the work ethics and culture._x000D_
_x000D_
PS: There is free food almost everyday in the office.
review_disliked_text: Having a startup kind of a culture, sometimes you can get more work leading you to stay in office for long hours.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1013906, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for this incredible review! We\u2019re delighted to hear that you love working at a place that values company culture and transparency. Your experience working longer hours is not uncommon at a company where everyone is eager to work on so many interesting projects. Keep up the good work, and thank you for all that you\u2019ve done so far to help APT grow.", "response_date_time": "2016-08-31T07:52:48.523", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_liked_text:
I can’t imagine a better community of people to work with. Everyone is intelligent and driven while still remaining humble, supportive, and team-oriented. The company culture is very strong - lots of free food, fun events, etc. I feel fortunate that I get to work alongside my friends._x000D_
_x000D_
I experience a lot of variety in my day-to-day work across multiple client teams, internal data team projects, and recruiting efforts (amongst other things). _x000D_
_x000D_
My favorite part about APT is the emphasis placed on the career review process. I appreciate that I receive actionable feedback every six months - I always have a clear idea of where I stand and what I can do to improve.
review_disliked_text: Being staffed on many teams at once - on busy weeks, this can lead to longer hours & lots of juggling priorities.

review_text: Keep investing in the development of the people of this organization.
review_liked_text: I've been part of this amazing company for 16 years. Here I've gotten the opportunity to live and work in different countries, enrich myself and family from  different cultures, have a network of friends and colleagues from many places in the world and with so diverse points of view.  I feel privileged and grateful at the same time as Mastercard has given me plenty of opportunities to develop my skills, broaden knowledge and my view of the world in a challenging and very demanding yet collaborative place.
review_disliked_text: We have many opportunities and problems as an organization. No question about it. But I think of them as challenges an opportunities to learn and enrich the world. We wouldn't have jobs in problem-free organizations.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1322553, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Congratulations on your 16 year anniversary!  Our people are our greatest asset, so thank you for being part our Mastercard team. We know that there is always room for improvement and we are committed to continuing to meet challenges head on, bundling our processes and developing our people. Thank you for taking the time to write a review.", "response_date_time": "2017-07-17T10:29:49.297", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]
job_title_text: Senior Vice President IMK Pricing & IC

review_text: none
review_liked_text: MasterCard has really good benefits and a bonus and profit sharing program that works well.  For the most part people are positive, friendly and helpful.  The company also focuses quite a bit on professional development of the staff by requiring development courses be a part of each persons performance review process.  They also conduct free seminars and invite subject matter experts to speak on common topics of interest such as personal finance.  There are opportunities to grow at Mastercard but as with any company you have to make an effort to market your personal brand so that you can be noticed by senior management.
review_disliked_text: Often there is too much red tape involved in executing good ideas.  As a public company the focus is now on the bottom line and less on people.

review_liked_text:
The type of work as an APM is incredibly diverse; you really get a chance to work with every role and on some really exciting new features and analytics. _x000D_
The engineering teams are relatively small and so you get to make a substantial impact and have a lot of ownership.   _x000D_
There is a strong culture of personal career growth and it is encouraged that you work on the projects that you’re really excited about. _x000D_
It’s pretty exciting to work with the data of so many large companies, and the incorporation of Mastercard data will make this even more exciting.
review_disliked_text:
Since it isn't a consumer facing product, it is sometimes harder to get excited about some of the upcoming features._x000D_
A heavy workload is pretty standard given all of the ownership and diversity of work.
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 665875, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thanks for leaving a review!  It\u2019s great to hear about all the things you love about APT.", "response_date_time": "2015-06-29T06:34:47.127", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: There's a cancer of culture that hides within political correctness that believes it can target and harm others at will. Take heed of what now former employees have left you, follow the complaints and paper trail.
review_liked_text: Great Cafeteria in Purchase, NY. Pay is above market.  Bonuses and benefits are really decent.  Lots of celebrations and free food and entertainment.
review_disliked_text: Some of the most inept managers in the industry, self entitled liars who manage up and will retaliate against employees. H.R. is useless and will tow the line to keep their jobs. Upper management is clueless as to what really goes on. There is a duality in what is preached compared to put into practice.

review_liked_text: APT provides every employee with the opportunity to get involved in so many different things, regardless of their seniority. Since joining APT, I have been involved in developing new analytics, worked with many different engineering teams, learned how to use a ton of new software products & helped out with recruiting. At APT, there is always plenty to do, and involvement is encouraged for every employee from interns to SVPs.
review_disliked_text: There are definitely times when it is hard to maintain an "ideal" work/life balance. APT definitely does not subscribe to a typical 9-5 workday, but the fact that everyone really enjoys what they are working on and the people they are working with, results in this being not as much of a con as it might be in other work environments.

review_liked_text: Love that my company cares enough to keep asking as well as providing tools, programs and ways to get ahead.  Not just financially but emotionally as well.  We have 5 paid days per year to volunteer to any of our favorite charities as well as an expanded pat leave globally...not to mention that #acceptancematters.
review_disliked_text: Takes a bit of time to learn about other teams and what they do or how you should align with them
employer_responses: [{"typename": "EmployerResponse", "count_helpful": 0, "count_not_helpful": 0, "id": 1448827, "language_id": "eng", "original_language_id": null, "response": "Thank you for taking the time to write a review.  At Mastercard, you can do well and do good at the same time.", "response_date_time": "2017-11-01T10:21:35.693", "response_original": null, "translation_method": null}]

review_text: Hire US citizens and stop discrimination against Caucasian men masked as “inclusive” when it is anything but. Start focusing on quality for customers.
review_liked_text: Great benefits except for medical. Great opportunities here for anyone that DOES NOT work in technology.  Also great for people from India or women.  Very Very bad place to be for male Caucasian men who are treated differently with less opportunities.  You don’t want to work here if you are very technical.
review_disliked_text: Marketing company that continues to market themselves as a technology company but is  very far from it.  Technical workers are treated like dogs and burned and churned.  Task masters rule with no technical backgrounds.  They focus on importing labor on H1bs into America vs hiring citizens and labor will work night and day to not be sent back to India. Other roles are fine there if you are from the CEO’s country of origin. Very poor quality software and products.

review_text: Hire more junior people to shoulder administrative work who can also learn and grow with the organization. Make org changes thoughtfully and communicate a plan and impact with the change (and limit how often this happens). Address company morale - it won't improve by ignoring it.
review_liked_text: Decent salary and bonus. Opportunities to move within the organization and have roles abroad. Reasonable commute if you live in Westchester or Connecticut. Flexibility to work remote although no company policy, it is at each managers discretion.
review_disliked_text: Organization is constantly changing and constant sense of waiting for the rug to be pulled out from underneath.  Lack of communication from Senior leadership down. When concerns are raised in people surveys, there does not appear to be any action to address it, just lip service. Very political environment.

review_liked_text: APT is growing and maturing quickly, and that growth creates lots of opportunities to contribute in big ways. Everyone has the chance to propose and work on their own initiatives, new ideas are encouraged and supported, and there is lots of opportunity for personal and professional development. I love the teammates who I work with, and I love the variety of the projects that we work on.
review_disliked_text: There is too much separation between the team that builds the product and the delivery team (ie business consultants and database analysts). The two teams would both benefit from each other's strengths by working more closely together, but APT doesn't seem invested in decreasing that gap (eg we are forced to use two different chat softwares - which makes it very difficult for the two groups to meaningfully interact)

review_text:
Authentically focus on diversity within talent pool (vs. PR opportunities)_x000D_
Decide what company stands for and build a real culture around it_x000D_
Stop investing in PR opportunities like perfume - no one wants to wear Mastercard perfume!
review_liked_text:
- Very generous benefits package_x000D_
- Half-day Fridays and quarterly no meeting days_x000D_
- Work anywhere 4 weeks a year_x000D_
- Broad range of development opportunities and skill development
review_disliked_text:
-Underlying misogyny throughout business, making it a challenging place for women to succeed; few women in higher positions (and almost no POC)_x000D_
- Cultural identity crisis - mishmash of cultures from acquisitions_x000D_
- Career advancement highly politicized, not transparent how promotions occur (although you have a better chance if you’re a white male!)

Authentically focus on diversity within talent pool (vs. PR opportunities)_x000D_
Decide what company stands for and build a real culture around it_x000D_
Stop investing in PR opportunities like perfume - no one wants to wear Mastercard perfume!
